DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

Form Letter No. 31

December 15th, 1931.

To Director of Medical Stores,
Dept. Pensions & National Health,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Kindly supply for the use of the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School the following drugs:

Rev. J. P. MacKay,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N. S.

as per attached requisition.

Rubbing Alcohol: Refer to Commissioner of Excise Letter No. 180291, dated December 12th, 1928.

F. H. Page,
Chief Accountant & Purchasing Agent.

Director of Medical Services
December 14th, 1931.

Dear Father Mackey,

We are ordering your drug requisition of December 1st with the following exceptions:

Mercurochrome solution would freeze at this time of year. You will receive a vial of mercuro-powder which the Doctor can dissolve.

Bichloride of mercury tablets are not supplied. You will receive chlorazene which is not poisonous.

Larkspur lotion cannot be had. See our recent circular on vermin, copy of which is enclosed.

Fruit salts are not supplied. I have increased the amount of sodium phosphate.

Caustic silver sticks - 200. Is this not a mistake?

It is directed that requisitions for drugs be certified by the Medical Attendant.

Yours truly,

Rev. J.F. Mackey,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N.S.

E.L. Stone, M.B.
Director of Medical Services

Ottawa, January 29th, 1932.

Rev. Sir:

I inclose triplicate of account for drugs shipped to your address by the Department of Pensions and National Health, on which the transportation charges have been prepaid.

Payment of this account has been made and the triplicate copy should be placed on file in your office for future reference.

If there are any shortages, they should be reported. Kindly do not show invoice to anyone not immediately concerned.

Rev. J.P. McKay,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N.S.

Yours truly,

F. H. Paget
Chief Accountant & Purchasing Agent.

Memorandum,

DR. SCOTT:

The report on the recent medical examination of the pupils of the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School indicates that 11 of them require operation for removal of tonsils and 11 others require correction of defects of vision. Davis, of 564 Barrington Street, Halifax, and William P. Short, 90 Gottingen Street, Halifax, have been similarly nominated as suitable to supply glasses. These men are not eye specialists but optometrists.

The funds available for this work are very limited and we are not prepared to use more than $200 for removal of 11 cases of tonsils, inclusive of the fees of the anaesthetist who will be the local school physician, and possibly those of a nurse. The work will be done at the school. The amount available for the surgeon would not be over $125.

The amount available for eye work is $75 which must include the fees for examination and the cost of spectacles.

It might possibly be better to have an eye, ear, nose and throat specialist who would do both the tonsils and the eye work, in which case we would be prepared to pay him $35 for examining the 11 pupils and purchase the spectacles ourselves on his prescription; or if he preferred he could have the $75 and supply the spectacles himself.
May I be informed whether Dr. Keddie and these optometrists at Halifax should be employed, or whether it is desired to designate a specialist and, if so, whom.

E.L. Stone, M.B.

Dear Sir,

Today I was asked by the Principal of the Indian Residential School here to take blood for Wasserman test from 160 pupils and that the Dept would pay $5000. The schedule fees given me by the Dept says $3.00 for taking blood for a Wasserman.

March 7th, 1932.

Dear Sir,

The Department has reason to believe that some of the pupils of the Indian Residential School at Shubenacadie are infected with syphilis, and wishes to have Wassermann Blood Tests made of all pupils in the school. It does not seem possible to make satisfactory arrangements to have this work done by the local physician, and I wish to inquire whether you have a Provincial Officer who could be assigned to do it. The Department is prepared to pay a nominal fee of $50.00 for the service, which you will agree is designed to protect the health of the province at large as well as that of the pupils and staff of the school. It is known that you have Provincial Laboratory facilities for examination of the specimens of blood, and it is assumed that these facilities are available to the Department without charge, as such services have often been in the past.

It may be well to add that it is the Department's intention to place any positive cases under active treatment, and it may possibly be necessary to ask you for some further assistance to this end.

Yours truly,

T.I. Byrne, Esq., M.D.,
Provincial Health Officer
& Deputy Registrar General,
Halifax, N.S.

Reverend Sir,

You will see that the Provincial Health Officer is being asked to communicate direct with you, and it will not be necessary for you to communicate this information to Dr. McInnes.

The Department has met with a difficulty in making arrangements for removal of tonsils from pupils of your school and would prefer to delay this matter until a later date. Short, of 90½ Gottingen Street, Halifax, for the examination of the eyes of the eleven pupils mentioned in the middle column of your letter of February 19th. This fee is intended to cover not only the examinations but the supply of glasses as well. It is not large but it is as much as the Department can provide at the present time.

Yours truly,

Rev. J.P. Mackey,

Reverend Sir,

In reply to your letter of March 22nd the Department is of the opinion that the MacDonald children should be got under treatment for syphilis without delay. A supply of neosalvarsan is being sent for this purpose and a further supply will be sent on request. Requisition for this drug should specify the strengths required and the number of tubes of each strength.

The Department has received a reply from the Provincial Department of Public Health in answer to its request for assistance in taking samples of blood at your school. The Provincial authorities do not wish to undertake this work for reasons which it is understood they expressed to you. It would be well for you to have a further discussion with Dr. McInnis on this matter. The Department considered that it was making a reasonably fair offer to him when it offered $50 for this work. He is not bound to do it at any particular time and should derive a substantial amount of business from treating the pupils who are found to be affected. Dr. McInnis' cooperation in this matter would be appreciated. The Department is anxious to do what is right and considers this to be a fair offer.

Yours truly,

Ottawa, April 8, 1932.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letters of the 25th ultimo and 4th instant, reporting a case of scarlet fever among the members of the staff at the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School.

In this connection it is noted that every precaution is being taken by yourself and staff to prevent this disease from spreading; and, so far, it is confined to the one case. It is hoped that the Reverend Sister who is ill with this disease will fully recover in due course and that no further cases will develop.

The action taken by Dr. McInnis regarding the cases of erysipelas and enlarged glands has been noted.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKee,
Secretary.

Yours respectfully,

April 16th, 1932.

Reverend Sir,

In reply to your letter of April 7th reporting on the cases of the MacDonald children, I may say that it will be in order for these children to receive treatment for syphilis at the rates laid down in Circular 9-1E of March 1st. It is important that treatment be carried to a proper conclusion and Dr. McInnis must be the judge in this respect. If as Dr. McInnis states it is impossible to find a vein in one of the children, he may secure the drug for intra-muscular treatment either from the Provincial Government or from any other source which deals in this class of goods and will give him a reasonable price. Only the standard drug is carried in stock and it would have to be purchased outside in any case. This child should not have to go to hospital.

These instructions may be taken to apply to any pupils of your school who are found to have syphilis in a communicable form or who require treatment of this disease. The account for the taking of the blood tests should be included in Dr. McInnis' regular monthly statement but the accounts for treatment should be placed on separate sheets and forwarded in the usual way.

It may be represented to you that it is not safe to keep these children in school among the other pupils. The Department's attitude in this respect is that pupils who are known to have syphilis and are under treatment are relatively safe to associate with. They may be and probably are less dangerous than some unknown cases among the pupils who have not been examined.

Rev. J.F. Mackey,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N.S.
Your other letter of April 7th containing a list of children who were examined by Dr. Melinnis on March 31st will be dealt with in a separate communication.

Yours truly,

A.F. MacKenzie
Secretary
Ottawa, April 21, 1932.

Rev. Sir:

In further reference to your letter of the 7th instant, regarding the examination of the pupils of the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School by Dr. McInnes, and giving the names of the pupils who require attention for tonsils and also those who require glasses.

In reply I have to say that, owing to orders for strict economy and our funds being extremely limited, it will not be possible to carry out all the above work which Dr. McInnes states is required. Only the more urgent cases should be given attention, and I would request that you check over the list of pupils and state the names of those whom it is absolutely necessary should receive attention for tonsils and also those whom it is absolutely necessary should receive glasses.

The Department has recently authorized the supplying of glasses to a number of the pupils, and the account of T. J. Davis, Halifax, who supplied the glasses, at a cost of $62.00, was received by the Department. This account has not been certified, and I return it herewith in order that you can certify same if you are satisfied that the glasses have been satisfactorily supplied.

Please return this account when you certify same, together with your report regarding the urgent cases requiring attention for tonsils and those requiring glasses.

Your obedient servant,

Rev. J. F. Mackey,
Principal,

Shubenacadie, N.S.

Reverend Sir,

With further reference to your letter of the 9th instant regarding pupils who require tonsillectomies, I would say that this authorizes the necessary operations. It should be understood that the instructions of the Department are that Dr. O.B. Keddy, of Windsor, should be engaged for the surgical work, and Doctor MacInnis should be anaesthetist. Arrangements should be made for the 26 cases to be done at Shubenacadie school in three or four groups in order that there should not be too great disturbance in the routine. For your information I would say that Doctor Keddy and Doctor MacInnis are expected to submit their accounts to the Department through Inspector Maxner. Accounts should reach Ottawa in three copies. The Department will allow the engagement of a nurse for the operating room if desired. The sum of $350 has been allocated for the fees of the surgeon, and this sum must include transportation and all other expenses incurred. The Anaesthetist will be allowed $100 for the work, and the sum of $50 must cover any other expenditures, such as extra nursing service, etc. The sum of $300 is expected to cover all expenses in connection with the tonsil operations necessary for the 26 children referred to.

I shall be glad to have your report of action taken in this connection.

Yours truly,

Rev. J.E. Burns,

Shubenacadie, N.S.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 7th inst. with reference to the pupils requiring tonsillectomies.

We have tried to make the necessary arrangements but without success. Dr. McInnis is asking for five dollars a case which means thirty dollars more than you stipulate. If another doctor is brought in his place it will mean possible complications and perhaps serious trouble. In the past Dr. McInnis has loaned us the operating table and if he is not there we could not expect to have the use of this table.

Frankly, after talking the matter over with many doctors, I am convinced that it is not fair to the children nor to those in charge of the school to have that work done there when there are hospitals within easy reach.

I know for a fact that I can obtain the services of two doctors who would be acceptable to the Department, and have the twenty six cases done for four hundred dollars, leaving one hundred dollars for the hospital with satisfaction guaranteed. Furthermore, if the work were done at the school it would mean that we would necessarily provide accommodation for at least one doctor and chauffeur, also three nurses for at least three days. And for at least a week the school would be upset during day and night. Our last experience with tonsils gave us many uneasy moments and we are not anxious to go through the same experience again.

We would like to have the work done before school closes, as a number of those listed will probably go home for vacation.

I hope that you will give the matter of having this work done in a hospital your serious consideration and that you will let me know just as soon as you can.

For the present please address any letters for me to Halifax Infirmary, Barrington Street, Halifax.

Yours very truly,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

August 12th, 1932.

Reverend Sir,

In reply to your letter of August 4th, this will authorize the expenditure of not more than $500 in tonsil operations for the pupils in your Residential School. Your plan of taking the children to hospital is approved, and it is assumed that you will utilise the Victoria General Hospital at Halifax. The Department has an arrangement with this hospital whereby Indian patients are accommodated at a rate of $2.00 per day, including the fees of the attending doctors. As it is improbable that the hospital would be willing to accept these cases under that arrangement, you may make any reasonable bargain with the Superintendent, which will provide for payment of the operating surgeon and anesthetist. The Department, however, would prefer to make all payments to the hospital, rather than to any doctors in Halifax.

If you can make such an arrangement you may proceed to have the operations carried out as may be convenient, and the Department is confident that you will use the available funds to the best possible advantage. The amount named must be understood as the whole sum available for all expenses in connection with this work.

Yours very truly,

August 16th, 1932.

No. 51-0-13

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 12th inst. The arrangements I can make for the tonsils is with the Halifax Infirmary. They have the same order of Sisters there as are at the School, and are interested enough to want the School get along. The arrangement calls for $200.00 for the Doctors and one hundred for the Hospital. That pays for the use of the operating table, nursing care, and the children will have three large rooms for themselves. We expect the average time for each child will be about sixty hours in the Hospital. The Hospital certainly will not average three dollars a day per child as the V.G.H. has. Surely in these hard times there will be no objection to us carrying out this arrangement. We expect to make a start on Monday next.

Yours very truly,

Shubenacadie, N.S., Aug. 29, 1932.

Dear Sir:

I find that the Agent got a letter on July 13th and an invoice from Ingram and Bell returned saying the Dept. would not pay for the $11.44 on the invoice. I never charged the Dept. $11.44.

There was one item on this invoice of $05 & 6% Sales Tax .48 = $8.53. This was for Sulphasphenium used in the treatment of Syphilis for Irene McDonald.

Last Spring I wrote through the Agent Mr. MacKey to the Dept. that I couldn't continue giving Irene McDonald the Nonarsm(?) as her veins were so poor. Mr. MacKey the Agent got a letter in reply stating that they did not carry in stock the Sulphasphenium but that if I secured it they would pay for it. Acting on this letter I secured the drug from Ingram & Bell. I was only charging $8.55 which is stated on my bill and not $11.44 which was the total of the invoice I got from Ingram & Bell (this invoice included other articles for my office). I wrote a long letter trying to make myself clear on this matter. Hope I did so.

D.F. MacInnis,
MC.DM.
Dear Sir:

Yesterday I sent on the account of the Halifax Infirmary, the amount being $500.00 for the twenty-six tonsil cases. Your letter of August 25th. ult. says that $300.00 is the amount. Either that was a mistake on your part or you misunderstood my letter of August 18th. If I had included the word "each" in connection with the fee of the doctors, it would have made things clear. The arrangement was that the doctors should divide four hundred between them and the balance go to the hospital.

The work started on Monday morning and the twenty-six were back at the school the following Saturday, all are doing well. The cost to the school for transportation did not amount to more than fifty cents per child. On the whole it was much better than having the work done in the school.

Dear Sir,

Your letter of June 19th received and contents noted. By doing away with the semi-annual examination of the school you have violated the agreement I made with the Dept. when I took over the school. Therefore am resigning and will have nothing more to do with the school. I am taking cognizance that this was what the Dept. had in view when they did this. I have been trying to keep down expenses and try to total well for the school.

poor copy
of the March examination was $100 from January 1st to date for this year, which I consider very good for 170 pupils.

The matter of economy has been carried too far already in the Institution as I understand. On March 13th I called at the school for to begin my semi-annual survey of pupils, after arriving at the school I was informed by one of the Sisters that they had a case of appendicitis in the school which began when the child collapsed at Mass on the morning of the 12th. I found she was a case of peritonitis and suggested getting her to a hospital at once. That night she was taken to the U.S. Hospital.
Halifax, was operated upon and a belly full of pus found and she died the next day. The case I refer to was Josephine Smith and I am asking for a thorough investigation of this case as I don't consider the people in charge of an institution which would cause such negligence fit people to be in charge.

If an investigation is not carried out I will have then Federal Member Mr. Obey bring up the matter on the floor of the House next session.

Father MacKey the Principal says the suggestion was his because the Dept did not carry the recommendations made at the Superintendent's

Yours Respectfully,

D.F. MacInnis, M.D., C.M.
June 30th, 1933.

Reverend Sir,

Doctor D. F. McInnis reports that on March 13th, he called at your school to begin his semi-annual examination of the pupils and that on arrival he was informed that one of the pupils had appendicitis, having collapsed at mass on the morning of the 12th. Doctor McInnis states that on examination he found that the disease had advanced to peritonitis and advised admission to hospital. He states that the child was taken to Halifax that evening and at operation was found to have free pus in the abdomen and died the next day. The child's name is given as Josephine Smith.

This report as made by Doctor McInnis constitutes a serious charge against the care given your pupils when sick. The Department has formed no opinion in the matter, having only Doctor McInnis' report. It must be recognized, however, that a professional report of this character carries great weight, and that the Department's duty is to enquire very carefully into the matter. Your statement in this connection will be appreciated.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

A. S. Williams,
Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of June 30th. ult. received by me on the evening of the 5th. of July, I suppose this report was received by you a few days before your letter to me on June 30th. Perhaps you will recall a copy of a letter sent to me under date of June 19th. No 9-51. The original was sent to Dr. McInnis informing him that there would only be one examination a year at the School in place of two. The morning I received this copy Dr. McInnis called on the phone and in no uncertain terms gave me credit or blame for the procedure taken by the Dept. in this matter. I am not going to even try to remember all that he said, only this, that from January till that date, he had received only twelve dollars for calls to the School. You can see from the reports that last winter and spring, we had very little sickness, unlike the previous year. It appears to me that the whole thing behind the belated report of the Doctor is nothing more or less than to compensate himself in some way for the loss of fifty dollars a year.

Now for the case of Josephine Smith. On Saturday March 11th, she was as active as any other child in the School, and like a good many more was suffering from a cold. A number of the other children had the cold that was going, and sometimes from coughing, especially in the mornings, would have a little stomach upset and vomit some.
On Sunday morning Josephine Smith felt weak and left the chapel, but returned in a few minutes. There was not any collapse. She remained around part of the morning, and as the other children were going for a walk she was sent to bed. We had no reason to think that her condition was any more serious than the others. That night she did a little more vomiting. Knowing that the Doctor was coming the following morning I asked the Sister to have the Doctor see this child before going on with his semi-annual examination. The Doctor usually arrives about nine, but this morning it was between nine thirty and ten. On his examination he said he thought it was a bad appendix, and advised taking her to the V.G.H. It was too late for us to get the ten after ten train and we took her in on the first through train, leaving here about four P.M. They operated that night about midnight and I saw the child early the following morning. The child died the following morning about eleven A.M. I was staying at St. Mary's Cathedral, and the hospital is in that parish. One of the priests was called and told that Josephine Smith was dangerously ill as she had developed pneumonia after the operation.

Now while the child was at the School she did not complain of any severe pain as one would expect from an perforated appendix. It would do me no good to ask for the report from the hospital, as it would not be given to me. So how much the Doctor is reading into or taking from the report I cannot say. I am sure of this that were Josephine Smith my own sister I could not under the same circumstances do any more for her. Apart from that the report of the health of the children in the School, ever since it opened speaks for itself. I wish you would write to Dr. Gosse of the V.G.H. and see what he has to say about the case. The Doctor seems to say that she died of peritonitis, which is not according to facts.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Dear Doctor:

With reference to your inquiry in the case of Josephine Smith, we beg to advise you that this little Indian girl, age 12 years, was admitted on March 15th, 1933, and died on March 15th.

On admission she complained of a "pain in the stomach", and gave a history that on the day previous to admission the pain came on in the pit of the stomach and she stated that she vomited before breakfast. On the day following she was examined by the doctor and sent to hospital, and admitted to the ward at 7.20 p.m.

The leucocyte count, on admission, was 24,000. She was examined immediately by the surgeons who reported a moderate rigidity of the abdominal muscles with moderate tenderness, on rectal examination, high up anteriorly. There was no tenderness on superficial abdominal examination.

Her condition was watched carefully, and at midnight it was decided to open the abdomen. The appendix was found gangrenous and free pus was found in the peritoneal cavity. The appendix was removed and the abdomen drained. On the morning following the patient was bright and comfortable and her condition satisfactory. That night, her temperature and respirations went up, and clinical examination showed a left sided lobar pneumonia. On admission she was suffering from a cold, and for this reason Chloroform anaesthetic was employed. The cold was evidently the etiological factor of the pneumonia. She died at 10.40 a.m. on March 15th.

We shall be glad to answer any further questions that may arise in this matter.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
M.D.,
Medical Assistant Superintendent.

Dear Sir,

Your letter of Aug 9th 1933 received and contents noted.

According to the Hospital authorities, the report sent you on July 25th states that the patient came to the Hospital with a ruptured appendix and was operated upon for this.

Did you or anyone else ever hear of a patient being operated upon and appendix removed? As a treatment for pneumonia?

The authorities at the School let this girl for 3-6 hours suffering with appendicitis after they themselves had made the diagnosis of appendicitis, and never called a Doctor to see her until I was only ¼ mile away from the School. I happened to call in...
at the School and insisted on seeing the child. When one of the sisters told me they had a very sick girl with a fever, I suggested to Father MacInnis the receipt of the School to get her at once to the town hospital which was the nearest hospital. Don't you think I have good reason for investigating and I am going to try every means in my power to get one.

August 18th, 1933.

Dear Doctor MacInnis,

The Department has received your letter of August 12th, and I wish to clear up any impression you may have that there has been from the beginning any doubt that the child Josephine Smith had appendicitis and that her appendix was found to be ruptured at the time of operation. You yourself made this report, and this fact has been taken for granted as common knowledge. The Department has no desire to prevent any reasonable investigation or conceal any of the facts. The hospital report gives the impression that the child was in good shape after her operation and might well have recovered if she had not been attacked by pneumonia. It is extremely regrettable that this child should have died but, on the basis of the facts as reported by yourself and so confirmed in detail by the Reverend Principal of the school, this appears to be an example of a case which occurs fairly frequently in private families, and of a condition which sometimes deceives the attending physician. It is doubtful, in the Department's opinion, if any Departmental investigation would reveal any facts not already disclosed. It is, however, your privilege, as a resident of the district, to take any action which you deem it your duty to take, and, as stated in a previous letter, you must judge for yourself in what direction your duty leads.

The Deputy Superintendent General of the Department, who is a physician, is now absent in Western Canada but will return within a few days. On his return the matter will be laid before him and it may be that he will take a different

MEMORANDUM.

DOCTOR MCGILL:

Doctor D. F. MacInnis, who attends the pupils of the Residential School at Shubenacadie, Nova Scotia, in a letter written late in June, informed the Department that on March 12th, on a visit to the school for another purpose, he was called to see a pupil who had been taken sick the day before and who the Sister in charge of the sick thought had appendicitis. On seeing the child he confirmed the diagnosis and, fearing that the appendix was ruptured, ordered the pupil to hospital. He states that he wanted her taken to Truro which can be reached in half an hour by automobile, but that the Principal insisted on waiting for several hours until she could be taken to Halifax by train. She reached Halifax in the evening, was operated on about midnight and the appendix was found to be gangrenous. Drainage was put in. She was in reasonably good condition the next day, developed a temperature that night and died on the following day of pneumonia. This is the substance of the information gathered by several reports from the doctor, the principal and the superintendent of the hospital at Halifax.

Doctor MacInnis demands an investigation and says that if the matter is not investigated he will see that it is brought up in Parliament. Two features of the case seem to me to be worthy of special attention. One is that Doctor MacInnis claims that the principal did not take his advice as to the immediate removal of the child to the nearer hospital. The other is that the doctor did
not think it necessary to report the matter until some three and a half months after the event, and seemed to do so then only because he had been informed that an examination of the pupils in the fall, which carries with it a fee of $50, would be dispensed with this year, as the Provincial Tuberculosis Clinic was to make an examination of the school.

We have endeavoured to preserve a strictly neutral attitude in this matter. It is not so very uncommon for a member of a private family to have appendicitis which goes on to peritonitis and death without anyone clearly recognizing the condition.

Whether a Departmental investigation such as Doctor MacInnis appears to want would serve any useful purpose I cannot say. I have of course discussed the matter with Mr. Sutherland and Mr. Phelan, and we should all appreciate your direction.

E. L. Stone, M. B.,
Director of Medical Services.

I have three children in the Residential School, Shubenacadie who gave a positive Syphilis test last year and were given a course of treatment by Dr. Macmillan Shubenacadie. November 13th, 1935.

Reverend Sir,

Levi McDonald, of Enfield, writes the Department to the effect that his three children who have had some syphilis treatment do not appear to have had further examination or treatment within the present school term. The Department knows Levi McDonald, and is not inclined to make too much of his complaints. He writes, however, in a straightforward manner about this matter and it is quite obvious that residential school pupils who have had treatment for syphilis should have their treatment followed up. I think the case should be brought to the attention of Doctor MacInnis at your earliest convenience so that he may decide upon and carry out whatever measures are necessary.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Sir:

Concerning the matter of the annual visit of the Dentist, during the past years the most work was caused by the new ones who apparently had no previous work done on their teeth. This was more pronounced in the case of those children who were just loosing their first teeth and the permanent ones coming in. As for the ones who have been here for three years, little and in some cases no work is necessary.

In looking over the children who have come here since October 1932 I find that out of eight there are five who require attention. In that five I would say there would be in the vicinity of twenty extractions, one youngster having at least eight.

Not knowing the rate paid to the Dentist I cannot estimate the cost for a visit this year, but I feel certain that the amount will not approach that of last year. If we cannot have this work done within the next month then on account of the road conditions, it will have to be put over till the spring, and in that case we will have plenty of tooth ache during the winter.

Please let me know as soon as you can.

Yours very truly,

Ottawa, November 25, 1933.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, requesting that dental attention be given to a number of the pupils of the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange with K. K. Dimock, D. D. S., Windsor, N. S., to perform the dental work absolutely required by the pupils at the present time.

The total amount available for dental services at the present time is $125, and the cost of the work carried out should not exceed this amount, as it will be impossible to make payment in excess. The fees allowed Dr. Dimock will be at the rate of $1.00 per filling, using amalgam or other cheap material; 50¢ per extraction of permanent teeth; and 25¢ per extraction of temporary teeth. In the case of temporary teeth, extraction only can be allowed.

The work should be done at the school - the dentist to supply all materials.

A list, in triplicate, should be prepared by the Dentist, giving the name of each pupil receiving attention and the number of fillings and extractions in each case. His account should also be prepared in triplicate, covering the amount due at the above rates. The account should be attached to the statement, certified by you in the usual manner and forwarded for payment.

Please arrange with the Dentist to perform the work at an early date. It is considered that attention should first be given to any new pupils who have entered the school. You should impress upon Dr. Dimock that the Department will be unable to pay for any dental work exceeding in cost the sum above mentioned, viz.: $125.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. J. P. Mackey,
Principal,

Kahn reaction Negative.

Remarks

Received Nov. 28/33 Entry No.: P.H. 3681

NOTE: The result of serological tests should always be interpreted in the light of clinical evidence. Where such interpretation cannot readily be arrived at, the submission of confirmatory specimens is recommended.

A negative blood Kahn reaction does not exclude the possibility of syphilis. A case of neuro-syphilis may yield a negative Kahn, but give a positive reaction with the spinal fluid.

The Kahn reaction does not become positive, except in rare instances, until about 8 weeks after the appearance of the primary chancre. Doubtful or weakly positive reactions in untreated cases, not showing the typical clinical features of the disease, should be repeated in two weeks.

January 3rd, 1924.

No. 51-0-13

Dear Sir:

Since writing you concerning Matthew Thomas, we have a little more information. In view of the fact that a certain individual is doing considerable talking, and the information received from the hospital yesterday that the kidney was removed and his condition only fair, I think we had better give you the details as far as we know them.

On Friday Dec. 29th, the coasting was good and a great number were at it. This boy Matthew Thomas who is about fourteen years of age takes with him two boys, younger than himself, away from the crowd, and goes over back of the root-house, where the hill is very steep. At the bottom of the hill is a road and then another sharp drop to the marsh and the river. I might say the tendency to get apart from the crowd has been a consistent attitude of this boy, and along with boys much younger than himself.

On this occasion they had gone to a place which they knew I had forbidden to go, principally on account of the steepness and roughness of the hill and the nearness of the river. When the accident happened the other boys put him on the sleigh and brought him up to fairly level ground where he got off and walked into the School. That was near supper time, and without saying anything went in and had supper. After supper he told Sister Margaret Patrice, the nurse, that he fell off his sleigh and that his elbow hurt his side. The truth is that he was thrown against
a fence pole or telephone pole and it certainly must have been with considerable force. The Sister found the flesh slightly broken and put a dressing on. The next day he said he was sore and remained in bed. The following day he wanted to get up and he remained indoors all day. On New Years morning he left the chapel followed by the Sister, nurse. After seeing him to bed she noticed the blood in the toilet. We called the Doctor and on his advice took him by car to the Hospital.

The Doctor says that the boy told him that he had passed blood on Friday night, but if that is true, it is also true that the boy did not make it known to any one here. Being the age he is one would think that he would make it known.

This is the case as far as I can find out from the Sister and the boys.

Yours very truly,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.
Shubenacadie Indian Residential School.

January 2nd, 1934.

Dear Sir:

Beg to inform you that we have two children at the V.G. Hospital in Halifax.

Mary Doucette, No. 03, was on the advice of the Doctor taken there on the evening of Dec. 26th. for observation, with the possibility of chronic appendix. They operated two days later and I saw her yesterday. She is doing well.

Matthew Thomas No. 27, got a bump while coasting and we brought him to the Hospital yesterday, Jan. 1st. We found about twenty four hours after the accident that he was pass-blood. Doctor McGinnis considered his condition serious, but at this time we have no word from the Hospital.

Yours very truly,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.

January 18th, 1934.

Reverend Sir,

In reply to your letter of January 13th I beg to advise you that every pupil who has been found to suffer from syphilis after admission to your school should have his treatment followed up and should be kept under supervision from this standpoint until he leaves the school.

In view of the considerable proportion of your pupils who have been found to suffer from this disease it would be advisable to have every pupil examined on entrance to school. The examination for syphilis should include a blood test, and if from this and other signs the Doctor makes a positive diagnosis treatment should be instituted at once and followed up.

I think you will find Doctor MacInnis reasonable in regard to his fees for these examinations and treatments. In most places this work is done by means of a weekly clinic and the Doctor is usually willing to compromise with the Department on fees by accepting a flat rate for each clinic held.

I think it would be advisable for you to make special arrangements with Doctor MacInnis for this work as it will probably go on more or less continuously for some years to come. The Department will be pleased to consider any reasonable proposals which you and he may be able to submit in this connection.

Yours truly,

Reverend J.P. Mackey,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
SHUBENACADIE, N.S.

February 16,
1934.

Dear Doctor MacRitchie,

I have your letter of February 13th enclosing report of the pupils at the Indian Residential School, Shubenacadie. This service is very much appreciated by the Department.

On examining the report I am pleased to find that by far the greater number of the pupils are considered free from tuberculosis. In a few cases I find pupils set down as suspected and a small number seem to be regarded as positive. Most of the last class are also stated to be arrested cases.

The practical use of this report is to enable the Department to decide whether some of these pupils should be removed from the school as real or potential sources of infection to the well. It is difficult for me to come to any conclusion from your report, and if I may further trespass on your kindness, I should be pleased to know whether you consider that any of these pupils should be so removed. I may say that it is the Department's intention to keep this school free of active tuberculosis.

Yours truly,

E.L. Stone, M.B.S.,
Director of Medical Services

J.J. MacRitchie, Esq., M.D.,
Department of the Public Health,
HALIFAX, N.S.

MP.
Dear Dr. Stone:

Yours of the 16th, to hand, re report of the pupils at the Indian Residential School, Shubenacadie. Report sent you is a copy of that filed in our department for our information.

I personally examine these pupils every year and am greatly interested in their welfare, and also greatly pleased with the progress in their physical condition from year to year. A number were classed Suspects and they will be carefully watched and checked up. Also a number were classed as Positive, but arrested cases. Most of these were glandular cases, some years back, and at present no activity.

In our classification, once positive, always positive, but state whether active, quiescent, inactive or arrested.

Taking the school as a whole, I considered them in splendid physical condition, at the time of examination, and all cases of tuberculosis or suspected, were inactive and non infective.

Formerly we checked up our suspected cases with X-ray, but as that has been eliminated we have to depend altogether on clinical examination.

Trusting I have conveyed the information you require, and shall be glad to do so at any time.

Yours truly,

J. J. MacKintosh, M.D.,
Divisional Medical Health Officer.

March 2nd, 1934.

Dear Sir:

Concerning Gladys Labrador and her teeth. When Dr. Dinock was here on his annual visit, the condition of her mouth and teeth was such that he would not touch them. He said that all her teeth should be extracted. On a previous visit he had taken out quite a number. At the time of his last visit this girl's teeth were not giving any trouble but lately she has had more than one ulcerated tooth. To add to the difficulty this girl is not strong mentally, and it is hard to know just what care she would take of a false set if she were provided with them. The case is further complicated by the fact that she is approaching eighteen years of age and as far as we know she has no living relatives. Would like to have her taken to a Dentist to see what he would advise and get some idea of the cost.

Yours very truly,

The Secretary,

Dear Sir:

The first report from the Hospital concerning Anna Madeline Bernard No. 667 was in answer to a telephone call from Sister Anita Vincent who accompanied the child to the Hospital. The child was operated on Wednesday evening and the inquiry was made early Thursday morning. The report was that her condition was good. Later on the same day, about two P.M., I received a call from Dr. Scammel that her condition was not good and that peritonitis was present. To date that is all we have heard, but I am afraid that at any moment we may get the report that the child has died. So I want to give you the details of the case as we know them here.

To begin with the child is not strong, and has often been indisposed, mainly on account of constipation. A laxative tablet and she would be alright again. Sunday morning she left the chapel and was sent to bed. Her breakfast was brought up to her, and she ate it. A laxative tablet was given and after a movement of the bowels, she felt much better. On account of not being strong she remained in bed Monday and Tuesday, having three meals and lunch in between. Her highest temperature was on Sunday, then 100. Had she been as strong as many others she would have been up on Tuesday. At no time was there any vomiting, or any indication of it. Dr. McInnis was in the School for two hours on Tuesday but the condition of this child was such that
that we did not think it was at all necessary to have the Doctor see her. Sister Anita Vincent was in to see her at recess time on Wednesday morning and the child did not complain of any pain then. Later on about eleven o'clock she said she had a pain in the right side. When the word came to me I called the Doctor, he was not home at the time, so I left the message for him to call and that I thought the girl had appendicitis. The Doctor came about one thirty and made his examination and ordered her to the Hospital. She arrived at the Hospital at four o'clock.

Looking back now, we might have acted in another way, but on account of the periodic spells of constipation, we thought that it was no more than that. I admit that we were wrong in our judgment but to say that we were careless and wilfully negligent would be unjust and unfair.

I am hoping against hope that the child will recover, but I am afraid that her condition is very serious.

Yours very truly,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs.

Nurse in Charge
To Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,

Re Mary Madeleine Bernard

Dear Sirs,

The M/n girl a pupil at the Residential School died June 6th at the U.S. Hospital, Halifax N.S.

The following is a copy of the Hospital report.

Admitted May 15th, a case of acute appendicitis of five days duration.

Operation on date of admission. The appendix was found acutely inflamed surrounded by foul smelling pus and general peritonitis was present. The abscess was drained, the appendix removed and an enterotomy done.
The patient developed a left basal pneumonia. For a few days it looked as though she would recover but she gradually grew worse. The patient had a heavy growth of streptococci. She died June 6th.

When Josephine Smith died last March 1933 under similar circumstances, I was criticized for not reporting the matter until some months afterwards.

I worked at the school on March 15th and never knew that Miss Bernard was ill. They called me in on May 16th and found she had been treated with Epsom salts, that she had severe peritonitis and I predicted then that the case
SHUBENACADIE, N.S.,

Would have a fatal termination. I notice the Hospital has her name Anna Bernard but Mary Madeline Bernard was the name she gave me and that they got me at the school.

I know from my experience with the Josephine Smith case that it is futile to report those cases to Dept as they probably feel as the Dept of School does that they go to Heaven and that it is not worth while trying to keep them poor Indian children alive.

Yours respectfully,

D.F. MacInnis, M.D.T.M.

MEMORANDUM

June 16th, 1934.

Mr. Buskard -

Re death of Anna Madeline Bernard at Shubenacadie Indian Residential School.

With reference to the above noted and in reply to your memorandum of the 11th June, I am enclosing for the information of the committee the Superintendent General copies of letters from the Principal of the Shubenacadie school with regard to this matter.

This was evidently a case of appendicitis in which the diagnosis was probably delayed by the physician being called into the case. Unfortunately this is by no means an uncommon occurrence even in private families. So often the patient is treated as a mild case of intestinal trouble before the persistence and severity of the symptoms induce the parents or guardians to call in medical assistance. This is evidently what happened in the case under review.

Whether an earlier operation would have saved the child's life or not is problematical. A formal investigation would be very unlikely to bring out further information in this case. Apparently we have all the facts available before us, and the only question at issue is whether or not the school authorities were culpably negligent in not calling in professional care earlier. In my opinion such a conclusion could scarcely be justified.

Ottawa, October 5, 1934.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, requesting that dental attention be given a number of the pupils of the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange with K. K. Dimock, D.D.S., Windsor, N. S., to perform the dental work absolutely necessary at the present time for the pupils of the school. The Department would prefer to engage Dr. Dimock for his services on the basis of payment of $30 per day. A day's work is estimated at 7 hours, during which the dentist is expected to apply his skill fully. He should furnish his own materials but is not required to provide gold fillings or any artificial teeth. Presumably, composition fillings are sufficiently good and no artificial teeth will be required. He should use anaesthetics sufficiently to avoid unnecessary pain.

Funds are available at the present time for not more than three days' dental work for the pupils of this school.

After his visit, Dr. Dimock should prepare an account, in triplicate, for the amount due at the above rate, and hand same to you, to be attached to proper voucher forms, certified and forwarded for payment.

Regarding the scale of payment allowed, I may say it is considered more satisfactory to engage dental services on a per diem basis than at a stated rate for each extraction and filling.

You should arrange to have the required work carried out as soon as possible. This dental work is to be performed at the school, and you can assist by organizing the clinic and seeing that the dentist is kept supplied with patients.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Dear Doctor,

In reply to your letter of Oct 13th I wish to submit the following:

The Province of Nova Scotia has no Provincial Venereal Disease Officer so I took up the matter with Dr. Frank Mack, Halifax, N.S. Who is Professor of Genito-Urinary Diseases at Dalhousie University and is also in charge of the Venereal Dept at the V.C. Hospital, Halifax.

He advised me that the
Course of 24 Injections

Course of Phenamine was the correct amount to give in those cases. He also advised to follow this up by about 17 injections of Bismuth in addition to the 17 injections Bismuth those already given. He then advised stopping the treatment except for about 6 injections Mercurox acid & Bismuth each year alternating the treatment. He was not in favor of Mercury inductions or Potassium Iodide except Potassium Iodide for a short period preceding the annual Course of arsenic and Bismuth.
I explained to Dr. Mack that those cases did not show any evidence of either acute or chronic venereal disease except by the blood tests. Dr. Mack tells me that where the blood has been positive he doesn't put too much reliance in a negative blood test without a spinal fluid test.

Yours respectfully,

Dear Sir:

Beg to let you know that we had a coasting accident on Sunday March 3rd. Charles Brooks "c." II about eight years old, was taken by Leo Finney No. 49, about 12 away from the regular coasting place among the apple trees which are surrounded by a barbed wire fence. The result was that the young fellow coasted into the fence and cut himself under the chin. Dr. McInnis was called and put four stitches in the cut. The youngster was put to bed for the remainder of the day, but was up yesterday and around with no apparent ill-effects.

Yours very truly,

The Secretary,

Shubenacadie Indian Residential School

Shubenacadie, N.S.
Sept. 14th, 1935.

Dear Sir:

This time next month it will be one year since we had a visit from the Dentist, K.K. Dimock, Windsor, N.S. During that time we have had at least thirty new children come to the School. A number of them require attention and no doubt some of the others also require attention.

Will you please let me know if it is the intention of the Department to have a dentist come this year, and under what terms.

Yours very truly,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
September 30th, 1935

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of September 14th regarding dental work for the children of the Shubenacadie School.

You may arrange to hold a clinic similar to that conducted last October. Doctor Dimock will be allowed the rate of $30.00 per day, but funds are not available for more than two days at the present time. An account similar to that submitted last year should be forwarded in triplicate to the Department.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie
Secretary

Reverend J. P. Mackey,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N. S.

LM
October 7th, 1935.

Reverend Sir,

This will confirm the arrangement made by Doctor E. L. Stone, Director of Medical Services, whereby Doctor C. C. Archibald is to select the pupils of your school who more urgently require removal of tonsils, and transfer them to hospital at Truro for operation. This will be done at such times and in such groups as you and he may decide upon when he examines the pupils.

Doctor Archibald is to receive $17.50 for each pupil operated on, and will arrange a favourable per diem rate with the hospital. It is hoped that he may be able to secure accommodation at the rate of $7.50 per pupil, to include two days' nursing care, or more if required, in reasonable degree, and the use of the operating room.

You will have to use your own judgment with reference to securing the consent of the parents to these operations. Technically you should do so, but in some cases it may be inconvenient, or even impossible, on account of distance.

Doctor Kent of Truro will give the anaesthetics at the request of Doctor Archibald. Accounts for pupils of the Residential School are to be forwarded to the Department through you.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Reverend J. P. Mackey,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N.S.

T.R.L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.
October 7th, 1935.

Dear Doctor Kent,

This will confirm the authority given by Doctor S. L. Stone, Director of Medical Services, for the removal of the tonsils of the five or six pupils of Millbrook Indian Day School who appear to require this operation. The work should be done at the hospital as usual. There will be a number of similar operations from the Residential School at Shubenacadie, and it is believed that you may be able to secure a favourable inclusive rate for hospital care of your group, similar to that for the other.

The Department would prefer that these operations be done by Doctor C. C. Archibald, who will operate also on the pupils from Shubenacadie. You will, it is presumed, give the anaesthetics for both groups. In such cases, where several operations are done at one time, the Department is often able to have the anaesthetics given for a somewhat less fee than is paid for a single minor operation. Perhaps you would consider $3.00 per child a fair remuneration in this case.

Accounts concerning the Residential School pupils should be submitted to the Department through Reverend Father J. F. MacKey, Principal, Shubenacadie Indian Residential School.

Yours truly,

T.R.L. MacLanes,
Acting Secretary.

H. V. Kent, Esq., M.D.,
Truro,
N.S.

Shubenacadie Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N.S.
October 10th, 1935

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find account of Dr. Dimock, dentist, for dental work done on the 7th and 8th inst.

At the rate of seventy-five cents for fillings and twenty-five cents for all extractions it would amount to sixty-six dollars. That rate is considerably lower than what has been paid in the past.

Please note that there were eighteen who were not examined at all. I felt that the doctor should have remained for another half day but he had booked appointments at his office and did not remain.

Yours very truly,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

SHUBENACADIE, N.S. October 5th, 1935

To the Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sirs,

I learned from the
Dept. of the Residential School
the other day that Dr. Archibald
from Truro called at the school
and looked the pupils over for
tuberculosis and took
of them to Truro and put
them in hospital. I am
to be the school physician
but I didn't hear any notice
of my dismissal and I didn't
know of any tourist work at
the school. I never heard
Dr. Archibald although I knew
Dr. Kent his assistant in the work
before. Consider this
the proper etiquette in
regard to an old employee
of the Dept. This tourist business
can be made a racket
and very often is a racket.

Yours respectfully,

D.J. MacInnis M.D., C.M.

Shubenacadie Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N.S.,
December 27th, 1935

No. 51-0-13

R

Dear Sir,

In reply to the letters of Doctor McGill, Deputy Superintendent General, dated November 21st and December 20th, I beg to say that the tonsil work was completed on November 1st, and the eye and ear work was done on December 6th, 1935. All the accounts for the tonsils have not come in yet, and no accounts as yet for the eye and ear work.

Doctor McLeod has his office in the village, so his address is Shubenacadie, N.S. (Dentist).

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Copy to Rev. Father P. Mackay.

January 2nd, 1936

Dear Sir:

Kindly refer any authorized dental work for Indians to Doctor McLeod, the dentist at Shubenacadie. You will find the fees for dental work in the Regulations for Medical Services.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie
Secretary

Allison McDonald, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Shubenacadie, N.S.

No. 51-0-13

Dear Sir:

Doctor MacInnis recommends that the child be sent to a Sanatorium as soon as possible. Will you please let me know if she may be placed in the Sanatorium at Kentville, N.S.

March 16th, 1936

Dear Sir:

Rev. Father Mackey reports that Clara Cinnish, a pupil of his school from the Burnt Church Reserve, has been found to be suffering from advanced tuberculosis and should be removed from the school. The Department thinks it right that she should go back to people whom she knows, and kindly see if arrangements can be made for her accommodation with some Indian family at Burnt Church where there are no young children and where she would be reasonably comfortable. The report on her condition is not very hopeful. If such arrangement can be made you may have to consider sending her to the sanitarium at Bathurst and you may do this without further correspondence if you find it necessary.

Father Mackey will receive a copy of this letter and you and he may arrange between you for the removal of the girl. The Department has read your letter of August 4th, 1932 in which you recommend her admission to school and judging from it would think her home conditions might not be at all satisfactory.

Yours truly,

C. Hudson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Richibucto, N. B.

A. F. MacKenzie
Secretary

LM
Richibucto N.B.
April 11th,
1936.

Sir:

In reference to your letter of March 16th, File 51-13, stating that Rev. Father Mackey had reported that Clara Ginish of the Burnt Church Reserve, and a pupil of his school, was suffering from advanced tuberculosis and should be removed from the school, I beg to inform you that this girl was placed in the Sanatorium at Vallee Lourdes, near Bathurst, on Monday the 6th instant.

As per your letter of March 16th, I made inquiry as to whether any kind of satisfactory accommodation could be had for her on the Burnt Church reserve, and I find that nothing suitable was available so I had her sent to the Sanatorium.

I also have to report that Peter Deam of the Burnt Church Reserve, who was an inmate of the above institution, died on the 6th instant.

Your obedient servant

SHUBENACADIE, N.S. May 1st 1936

To Mr. J.P. MacKay
Principal Residential School

Today I examined the following ear cases and report is as follows:

1. Emma Condo - Chronic otitis media with a large perforation in ear drum. Addicott's ointment.

2. Teresa Battiste - Chronic otitis media with cerumen and discharge in ear canal. Ceruloid towels to be used. Will syringe ear tomorrow.

3. Wm. Gibson - Chronic otitis media and eczema of ear. Treating eczema. Should take him to ear specialist.

4. Barney Clare - Hemorrhage in ear canal which has discharged and is getting well at present.
D. J. MacInnis, M.D., C.M.

SHUBENACADIE, N.S.

5. Joe Knockwood - Cerum in both ears. Will spring them tomorrow.

6. Charles Brown - Enlarged tonsils today.

7. Herman Somerville - Cerum and pus in ear. Will spring tomorrow.

Yours sincerely,

D. J. MacInnis, M.D., C.M.

Mary from Langley, enlarged tonsils and discharging ear.
Shubenacadie Indian Residential School.
Shubenacadie, N.S.
May 5th, 1936.

No. 51-0-13

Dear Sir:

Attached please find a report of Dr. McInnis concerning children who have been bothered with running ears. With the exception of Wm. Gahue, Barney Clare, and Joe Knockwood, the Dr. attributes the trouble to enlarged tonsils.

We also have a number with decayed teeth, some had not been attended to last fall when the dentist was here and the others have come to the school since that time.

If this ear trouble is caused by the tonsils, would it not be possible to have these cases looked after without delay. There would not be more than six at most.

Since the local dentist is to do the work I do not suppose that it will make any difference whether it is done in small lots or not. If you have arranged a schedule of rates I believe the dentist would rather take them in small groups.

Will you please let me know what I may do in regard to tonsils and teeth.

Yours very truly,

The Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs.

May 7th, 1936.

Reverend Sir:

In reply to your letter of May 5th, I regret that the Department cannot provide a tonsil and dental clinic for your school, at the present time. It would be pleased to do so, except that your pupils had the advantage of very considerable work of this kind last fall, and there are many schools calling for similar work where none has been done for at least two or three years. The funds provided by Parliament will not cover the cost for all, and preference must be given to those which have had to wait.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie

October 12th, 1936.

The Secretary,
Dep't of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa

No. 51 - 0 - 13

Dear Sir:-

It is a year this month since any dental work has been done for the children here. We have had twenty-nine vaccinated and would like to know what can be done as far as teeth are concerned. Certainly some of the new children need attention, and also about twenty others who did not see the dentist last year. The two days allowed to the dentist last year did not permit him to see all the children.

As for tonsils there has been no general examination but I remember one whom Doctor MacInnis said should have his tonsils removed. How many others there would be, I cannot say. If possible we would like to have these matters attended to before the winter.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

October 19th, 1936

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of October 12th I may say that under the financial conditions just now obtaining, the Department is unable to guarantee a dental or tonsil clinic for this fiscal year. If the situation improves it may be possible to arrange something a little later on. You may take some comfort from the fact that the Department has rarely ever been able to provide clinics of this kind at every school every year.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie
Secretary

Rev. J. P. Mackey,
Principal
Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N. S.

LM
Indian Residential School,
Simcoe, N.S.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa

No. 51 - 0 - 13

Dear Sir:

Received your letter yesterday concerning teeth and tonsils, saying that no funds are available at the present time for this work.

Since last October, there have been forty-nine children, twenty-eight girls, and twenty-one boys admitted, and Doctor MacInnis and Doctor MacRitchie, public health doctor, both tell me that there are some bad tonsil cases, and as would be expected among the new ones, many decayed teeth.

We are sending in this morning the expense account for dismissals and vacations. We hope the school funds will as usual be reimbursed for this amount. If so, would you give your approval to allow us to spend that amount on tonsils and teeth? If so, we should be left free to make our own arrangements and get the most work possible done for that amount of money.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Dear Mr. Spinney:

Received your letter this morning. Perhaps I did not make my meaning clear to you. From what information I have, it is just a matter of time until Pauline Phillips will be well again. As far as the Victoria General Hospital not being the proper place for her, to me that appears to be a very serious statement for one to make. Again, the same applies to what the grandfather said to you.

Before any transfer from one hospital to another can be made, I think it would be necessary to have the matter brought to the attention of the Department. With that in mind, I am writing them this morning. No doubt you already have done so. As soon as I receive any information from the Department I will let you know.

Yours very truly,

November 17, 1936.

Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N.S.

Rev. J.P. Mackey, Superintendent

Dear Sir:

I received your letter this morning advising me about the condition of little Pauline Phillips. I am sorry that her condition is not as it should be, and according to your letter and what it would appear to me that Pauline is going to be sick for some time and I do not think the hospital at Halifax is the place for her and I can have this little girl brought from the hospital there and have her removed to the hospital here in Berwick.

And if need be, I can take her to me home until something else turns up. I feel sure she will not be able to go back to school again this fall and winter and her grandfather, Isaac Phillips, has asked me to have his little girl brought back home.

This morning I had a call from Isaac Phillips, grandfather of the child and he tells me that he has been to the Victoria General Hospital and seen his little girl and he tells me that all the little girl had on was a little cotton dress and was not getting the attention she should have.

Mr. Phillips wishes to have his little girl sent home and placed in a hospital handy home, so he can go and see her any time he wishes. Pauline is very homesick and wants to come home, and under these
circumstances I have decided that Pauline be sent home, and I will have her looked after from this end.

I have written the hospital telling them just about what I am telling you and for them to advise me just when I can send a car for her. Please let me hear from you about this matter. I remain

Yours truly

(signed) Clarence Spinney

Indian Agent

Kentville
Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N.S.
November 18th, 1936.

The Secretary,

No. 51 - 0 - 13

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find copy of letter of Agent Spinney, Kentville, and copy of my reply to him.

The girl in question is Pauline Phillips, No. 0164.

On Sunday, November 1st, this child with no pains or aches was running a temperature of 101-102. The Doctor was called and came every day until the child was taken to the V.G. Hospital on Friday, November 6th. The second or third day here she passed a large worm and the Doctor thought that was the cause of the temperature. But even after that, the temperature continued. From what I heard the hospital authorities declared that she has water on the lung.

I had written Agent Clarence Spinney twice to inform him of the girl's condition. This is the first time I ever heard of the Agent giving instructions to the hospital when the child was admitted to the hospital from the school.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

November 23rd, 1936

Dear Sir:

Reverend J. P. Mackey, Principal of the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School has sent to the Department a copy of your letter to him of November 17th on the case of Pauline Phillips. It is very possible that you may not know that the pupils of an Indian Residential School are wards of the Principal during their residence at the school and even during the summer holidays when they are home. He is, in effect, their Indian Agent and even more than that, their personal guardian.

You were, therefore, in error in instructing him if you meant to do so, to have Pauline Phillips sent home. I am sure this arose through misunderstanding and am pleased to have an opportunity to inform you of the correct view to be taken.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie

March 30, 1937.

Reverend Sir:

Doctor MacInnes informs the Department that there are a number of children at your school who are deaf and that he is doubtful of the wisdom of keeping them in the school. He mentions three children of a Brooks family, Stephen Morris and Irene Martin. This is a matter on which the Department would be pleased to have your report and opinion.

Doctor MacInnes says that all the children mentioned above and Harriett Baptiste require removal of tonsils and adenoids. In October last you proposed to carry out, at the expense of the school, a clinic for this purpose and also a dental clinic. It is not known whether you have done this or whether you thought better of your proposal afterwards. The Department would be pleased to know whether these children could be taken care of under that plan.

Doctor MacInnes says that you are in hospital. The Department hopes for your early recovery.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes
Secretary

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of March 30th, what Doctor McNutt says about the three Brooks boys, Stephen Morris, Irene Martin, and Harriet Battiste, is true enough.

As for the Brooks boys, the oldest, Dennis, came to the school three years ago. We had his admitted to the V.G. Hospital for ear treatment and they could do nothing with his ears, but remove his tonsils. His general health improved, but not his hearing. I wrote at that time that it was impossible for us to do anything with him. We could not keep him quiet in the class-room and one had to shout at him to make him hear. At the close of the school year, we suggested that under the circumstances it would be better for him to remain at home. This was done. But the next year with a new Agent at Annapolis Royal, you apparently received letters saying that this boy should be in school. The idea of sending him to school for the Deaf and Dumb was considered too expensive. The result was that he and two younger brothers came last fall. As one was already here, that makes four in all. Of the four, three are quite deaf and with a school attendance of over 160, it is impossible to do very much for these boys. The Agent thought we could give them individual attention, but with the crowd we have, that is not so easy.

Irene Martin is very deaf, but I don't think anything can be done to improve her condition. As for Stephen Morris and Harriet Battiste, removal of tonsils may help.

As for the tonsil and dental clinic. The sum of $68.00 was paid for dismissals and vacation tickets. When you said there would be no money for tonsils and teeth, I suggested that we might use the $68.00. We started with those children whose teeth were in bad condition. We had fifty-odd attended to, at a cost of $50.00. Knowing that the remaining $18.00 would not go far on tonsils, we did not start.

At the close of the year, March 31st, with a balance of $77.07 in the bank, we have outstanding accounts amounting to over two thousand dollars, so with prices still going up, we do not feel any too secure. However, if you say we will go ahead and have tonsils and adenoids removed. But if this work is to be paid for from school funds, then we must choose the place and doctors. To be perfectly fair, in the past we have had work of this kind done at less cost than the Department has paid.

I was in the hospital for five days, but back to normal again. Thanks! Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Extract from letter from Rev. J.F. Mackey,

"October 13, 1937.

"Since the Department is having the T.B. Test for all children at considerable expense, we suppose that it is not possible that there will be any funds for teeth and tonsils. If we can we expect to do the same as we did last year with vacation expenses, that is, spend it on teeth or tonsils, or possibly some for both."
October 21, 1937

Reverend Sir:

Replying to a part of your letter of October 13 I may say that the Department is able to find moderate funds for dental and tonsil clinics this year in addition to any special work it is trying to do in the control of Tuberculosis. I should be pleased to receive from you any application you may wish to make for clinics of this kind and am sure that if you are able to provide any funds out of your school money you will do so in addition to what you ask the Department.

Yours truly,

May 5th, 1936.

No. 51-0-13

Dear Sir:

Attached please find report of Dr. McInnis concerning children who have been bothered with running ears. With the exception of Wm. Gemue, Barney Clare, and Joe Knockwood, the Doctor attributes the trouble to enlarged tonsils.

We also have a number with decayed teeth. Some had not been attended to last fall when the dentist was here and others have come to the school since that time.

If this ear trouble is caused by tonsils, would it not be possible to have these cases looked after without delay. There would not be more than six at most.

Since the local dentist is to do the work, I do not suppose that it will make any difference if it is done in small lots or not. If you have arranged a schedule of rates I believe the dentist would rather take them in small groups.

Will you please let me know what I may do in regard to the tonsils and teeth?

Yours very truly,

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6058, file 265-13, part 3)
November 22, 1937.

Reverend Sir:

In reply to your letter of November 15 I may say that dental attention for 31 children would normally require the time of a dentist for about one full day, or a little more. The fee for a day's dental clinic is $30.00 but the Department will allow up to $40.00 if necessary. You may have the work done as found most convenient, but I would suggest that you get the dentist to come to the school for a clinic, or alternatively make his time available at his office for at least one clear day.

If there are not more than six children for removal of tonsils, the best method would seem to be to take them in one group to the hospital at Halifax. This plan is proposed on the assumption that they can be admitted to the Victoria General Hospital under the usual arrangement with that institution. Individual consent of the parents is required before the operations are undertaken.

The dental work may be done by Doctor D. O. McLeod of Shubenacadie.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of November 22nd, concerning teeth and tonsils:

Doctor McLeod, the local Dentist, made a start at the teeth, and he has agreed to do the thirty one children for Forty Dollars. So far we have taken twelve to his office, consuming two afternoon office hours. Three of these twelve have to return, as they have so many teeth to be extracted, that it will require an anaesthetic. Doctor McInnis has agreed to go to the Dentist's office to give the anaesthetic. You can readily see that it is going to take more than two full days. This can be partially accounted for, on account of the Dentist's eye trouble, a war disability, which does not permit him to do fast work. However, we hope the work will be cleaned up in about two weeks.

As for tonsils, from our own observation, we felt that there were at least six who required tonsillectomy. When the Doctor examined these six, he continued to examine those who came to the school since the last lot of tonsils were done. To our surprise he has listed twenty-six for tonsils, and three for adenoids. The three for adenoids are of one family, and with the exception of one member of that family, they all had bad cases of bronchial catarrh. Of the twenty-six tonsil cases, there is no choice; one is as bad as the other.

Will you please let us know if you have any funds for this work, and if so, what Doctor is to do them?

Enclosed is the statement of Doctor McInnis.

Yours very truly,

P.S. We are quite sure that we could arrange to have the tonsil work cared for at an average cost of $15.00 a case, during the Christmas holidays. At that time of the year there are not so
many patients at the hospitals and the Doctors are not so busy. Our plan would be to take about eight at a time to the Halifax Infirmary. The cost would be much less than the last group who were done about three years ago. Supposing that for the present at least, the cost was cared for from school funds, would there be any objection?

Will you please let us know as soon as possible, so that if necessary, we can make all the arrangements.
December 13, 1937

Reverend Sir:

With reference to your letter of December 7, I wish you would state definitely whether or not you are prepared to have a tonsil clinic of the size indicated in your letter, carried out at your school.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes
Secretary

Principal,

Shubenacadie, N. S.

Knowing that we have not the necessary accommodation, and recalling the experience of a similar clinic some years ago, we are absolutely opposed to having the work carried out at the school.

Yours very truly,

Reverend Sir:

I regret that for various reasons a reply to your letters of December 7 and December 17 has been deferred. This is on the subject of tonsil operations for your pupils. The Department is reluctant to think that 26 children definitely require the removal of tonsils. Reasonable funds are available and this will be your authority to have the twelve most urgent cases operated on at any hospital in Halifax where you can make good arrangements. It is thought that an inclusive rate of not more than $20.00 should cover this work. In your letter you mention $15.00 and it will be so much the better if you can get it done at this rate.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:-

Enclosed please find receipted accounts for the sixteen cases of tonsilectomy. Doctor MacInnis again went over the twenty six cases and the "very bad" numbered sixteen. Allowing Twenty Dollars ($20.00) each for twelve, as stated in your letter of January 14th, the total amount of $240.00 would cover the charge for sixteen at Fifteen Dollars ($15.00) each, so we had the sixteen done. The travelling expenses were higher than we figured on account of a bad storm, but even at that, it was much better than having the cases done in the school.

We are having our share of "flu" and so far two cases of pneumonia. For these two cases it became necessary to have an extra nurse for seven nights. We hope it won't be necessary again, as Four Dollars each night soon runs into real money.

As you see, we paid for the tonsils, and I would be grateful if you would send the check for $240.00 here, to the credit of the school funds.

Yours very truly,

June 13, 1936.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,

Ottawa

No. 51 - 0 - 13

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find two letters from Doctor McInnis. One concerns No. 06, Gladys Labrador, who, according to the Doctor and the X-Ray plates taken recently by the Dept. of Public Health Officers, is an active T.B. case. We are requesting that you give us permission to have this girl admitted to the Sanatorium, at Kentville. She has no home.

The other letter concerns No. 165, David Bernard. The Doctor suggests that he be taken to the Halifax Infirmary, to have his tonsils removed.

No doubt his suggestion is prompted by the fact that when the last group of tonsils were done, they were taken to the Infirmary. We do not see how we could have this one individual case done at the Infirmary, at a more reasonable rate than at the Victoria General Hospital. So we suggest that he be sent to the Victoria General Hospital, where the rate of $3.00 a day would be the only charge.

We would be pleased to hear from you soon, especially concerning the case of Gladys Labrador.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
