June 17, 1938

Reverend Sir:

Reference Your Letter June 15, Gladys Labrador, David Bernard

Gladys Labrador may be admitted to any sanatorium where a bed can be found for her, but the Department earnestly wishes that Doctor McInnis would use the official examination form so that it may be known who made the examination and what the other circumstances of the proposed patient are.

David Bernard may be sent to any suitable hospital in Halifax or elsewhere to have his tonsils removed. If he has any parents their consent must be obtained before the operation is undertaken.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes

September 14, 1936.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa

No. 51 - 0 - 13

Dear Sir:

By the time that all the children are here we will have about thirty five new ones. Some of these already here are complaining of tooth ache.

Also it is certain that there will be some for tonsillectomy. Will you please let us know if there are any funds available for this work? On account of whooping cough on a few of the Reserves, some of the children approved by the Department have not arrived, especially the Reserve of Mr. Langley, at Barra Head.

Last year the tonsils were not done until February, and we would like to see the matter attended to this year before the weather becomes cold.

The financial arrangements made last year, at $15.00 a case, we think were satisfactory to the Department, and we feel certain that we can do as well this year.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Reverend Sir:

Ref. your letter Sept. 14 - Tonsil and dental work.

This will be your authority to have the most necessary tonsil operations done in the same manner as you did last year by conveying the children to any hospital at Halifax where the work can be done at the cost quoted in your letter. The consent of the parents must be obtained and the admissions to hospital covered by Doctor McInnis' written recommendation on the official form.

With regard to the dental work, this will authorize an expenditure of $60.00, which you may use in the most productive manner, employing the services of the dentist at Shubenacadie. This would provide for two days dental clinic at the school, but you may wish to take individual children to the dentist's office often, in which case the Department trusts that the same return may be obtained for the outlay.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find letter of Dr. MacInnis, concerning James Paul, who came from Barra Head, Mr. Langley's Agency, on September 19th, 1938.

Not having seen the application for admission, we do not know whether the condition of this boy was noted by the examining Doctor or not.

Dear Sir:- No. 51-0-13

Re: to inform you that James Paul, No. 177, died at the V.C. Hospital early Sunday morning, November 13th.

This boy came to the school from Barra Head, Inverness County, on September 19th. The night he came, enlarged glands in the neck began discharging. These glands were healed up pretty well before he went to the hospital, on November 3rd, but from verbal reports received from the hospital, he was an active T.B. case. As we said in a previous letter, we are quite convinced that this boy should not have been admitted to the school.

This is the second death within a month, and both Joyce McDonald, and James Paul, came to the school since the first of September.

We do not know what your policy is for burial expenses, but we are paying them from school funds. In the case of Joyce McDonald, the expense for her sickness and death will come to at least one hundred dollars ($100.00). For James Paul, we have not received the accounts, but we do not expect they will total less than Fifty Dollars.

Enclosed is a letter from Doctor MacInnis. We do not wish to make any comment on it.

Yours very truly,

P.S. The enclosed letter was written but not mailed when we received word that the boy James Paul was too ill to move, and he died within twenty-four hours later.

Shubenacadie, N.S.

Dear Sir:

With regard to James Paul, No. 177, we wrote to you about this boy on September 22nd, and have your reply of the 24th. We kept this boy separated from the others as much as possible, and gave him all the treatment we could. The gland condition in the neck cleared up very well, but just about the time it cleared up, he contracted a cold and bronchial condition. Soon after receiving your letter of September 24th, we got in touch with the Public Health Department, in order to have the boy examined and X-rayed. Up to the time the boy developed the cold and bronchial condition, the Public Health Doctor had not come. Doctor MacInnis considered it advisable that the boy be sent to the V.G. Hospital, at Halifax. This was done on November 3rd, and no doubt you have the form covering this case on your file.

We were informed by telephone from the V.G. Hospital, that the boy is an active T.B. case, and the authorities there suggest that he be sent to the hospital at Kentville. Doctor MacInnis got in touch with the authorities there, and as far as we understand it, they are willing to take the boy immediately, but want authority from the Department of Indian Affairs. This being the case, we are taking it upon ourselves to assure the authorities at the Sanatorium that the charges will be paid by the Department, before receiving such authority.
Naturally, the doctors at the V.C. Hospital do not want to keep him there any longer than they can help, and if it were only a matter of a few days, they would keep him and send him direct to Kentville. Otherwise, if we had to wait for your permission, it would mean that the boy would be sent back to the school, and then on to Kentville.

So all things considered, we think we are doing the right thing in assuring theatorium that the charges for this boy will be paid by the Department. We hope that we will have your approval.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

I would like to know if a certificate of good health was sent by the examining doctor to the Dept. and if not who feared the certificate at Ottawa and recommended that this boy be sent to the school.
I feel that it must have been some clerk in the Deptt and not any of the medical staff I shall pleased that we did everything possible to keep him away from the other pupils.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find the account of the Halifax Infirmary, and Doctor Arthur L. Murphy, for tonsil work, authorized in your letter of September 21st, 1938. Six cases only were done. Doctor MacInnes, in his examination of the children, found that sixteen should be done. We took eight to the Infirmary, but two were not done - one on account of a slight infection of the throat, and another on account of a cold. About the same time, we had an epidemic of whooping cough, and considered it not advisable to have the other ten done. No doubt in the next examination they will be included in the number for tonsillectomy, along with a few of the new ones who have come since the last examination. As it is near the close of the year, it might be that your funds for this work have been spent, if so, will you let me know and we will pay the account from school funds, with the hope that the school will be reimbursed later.

Yours very truly,

Rev. J.P. Mackay.

To Rev. J.P. MacKey,
Principal Residential School,
Dear Sir,

We are apparently getting all the advanced T.B. cases and possibilities in the three provinces shipped into our school and apparently there is no way left for us to keep them out. It is very unfair to the children who are clean and well and are attending the school.

James Paul was sent to us last fall in such an advanced state of T.B. that he died before we could get him to a sanatorium. The Doctor
Who examined him before he came to us stated this on his application form but the Dept ordered his admittance to the school. Just the other day we had Simon Paullette shipped to us and he is 4 ft syphilitic.

Please impress on the Dept at Ottawa that this is not a T.B. Clinic and a syphilitic home and the importance of protecting the health of the other children who come here. With the impression that it was a Residential School.

D.F. MacInnis

February 16, 1939

Reverend Sir:

I have read Doctor MacInnis' letter of February 11 about James Paul and Simon Poulette and I know it is not the Department's intention to have tuberculous children admitted to your school. I am told that the admission of James Paul was a clear error such as sometimes occurs in the best organizations. I am not so clear that the admission of the other boy was a mistake. If he requires treatment he is in a good place to have it and I believe a few treatments will render him quite harmless to anyone else. I can understand Doctor MacInnis' impatience.

Yours truly,

E. L. Stone, M. B.
Superintendent of Medical Services

Dear Sir:

Re: Surgery for the Indians of Colchester and Hants County, N.S.

Any eye, ear, nose or throat work (other than tonsil operations) performed at the Truro Hospital for the Shubenacadie Reserve or School should be given to Dr. J. W. T. Patton, of Truro, N.S. Tonsil operations for this Reserve and School performed at the Truro Hospital should be given to Dr. J. B. Reid, of Truro.

If any tonsil work is carried out for the Shubenacadie School, it should be given to Dr. D. C. Reid, of Windsor.

All eye, ear, nose and throat work, including tonsil operations for the Indians of the Hilden Reserve in Hants County should be given to Dr. J. W. T. Patton, of Truro.

April 30, 1929.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa

Dear Sir:

A boy developed a sore throat on Tuesday last. A swab was taken and the report was diphtheria. By the time the report came the boy was not the least bit sick. Two days later a girl became sick, but no sore throat, and the report from the Lab. was again diphtheria. Those who had been in contact with the boy had swabs taken, about five in all, including the Sister Nurse, but those were negative.

Needless to add we are under quarantine.

Apparently it is a very mild type, but we are taking every possible precaution to stop the spread.

We are obtaining our supply of anti-toxin from the Public Health Authorities of this Province.

Yours very truly,

No. 51 - 0 - 13

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find accounts from the Department of Public Health, for anti-toxin, toxoid, and Schick Test Materials.

All cases have been exceptionally mild. Nasal and throat swabs were taken of all, and, with the exception of two boys who were negative to the Schick test, all were reported negative or no growth. However, these two boys were positive on the swab test, and the Doctor has classed them as probable carriers. Needless to say, they were immediately segregated, and we hope to have negative tests for them soon. In the meantime, we are under quarantine.

For the past week there have been no more positive cases. In the beginning every child who complained of sickness, was given anti-toxin, but in most cases, the swab test showed them negative. It may be necessary to have a little more material for toxoiding, especially for the first treatment. We understand that this can be purchased in a quantity sufficient only for two persons. The usual supply we used contained enough for twelve children. The Doctor thinks it possible that we may have the odd case for a few months, and we are, therefore, keeping a small supply of anti-toxin on hand.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

June 1, 1939

Dear Father Mackey:

We have here your voucher of $102.80 for diphtheria antitoxin and toxoid supplied by the Department of Public Health at Halifax. The date of the account is May 10.

My attention has been drawn to the very large number of doses of 10,000 units of antitoxin. There were altogether 57 such doses supplied.

At this distance I should have supposed that those actually having the disease would be given 10,000 or more units, the immediate contacts about 1,000 each and the rest treated with toxoid. You reported 5 actual cases of diphtheria.

It would ease our minds if Doctor MacInnis would give you a statement to send here. I am enclosing an additional copy of this letter which you may wish to give him.

Yours truly,

E. L. Stone, M.B.
Superintendent of Medical Services

Rev. J.P. Mackey,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N.S.

IM
To Rev. J.P. MacKey
Principal Residential School

Dear Sir,

In reply to a letter from Dr. Stone re-use of antitoxin at the school I beg to supply the following information.

In handling the epidemic I followed the course advised by the Deputy Minister of Health for Nova Scotia and the course advised by all modern epidemiologists. I used 35 doses of 10,000 units antitoxin and had 35 cases of diphtheria clinically and only 5 cases proven to be so by lab.
The other 30 cases were Diphtheria clinically and had the same condition as the other five as far as illness and other clinical signs could be made out.

To those Clinical Cases I gave 10,000 units and sent a swab to the lab. If the report was negative no more antitoxin was given.

Contacts were not given any antitoxin until they showed clinical signs. The giving of 1000 units to contacts and leaving them liable to anaphylaxis in large doses has to be given is not in my opinion a good practice.
I hope the above explanation will be sufficient.

I did not use any method of treatment peculiar to myself but followed what I considered the modern method of treatment. I also consulted Dr. P.S. Campbell of the Dept of Public Health for Nova Scotia and he advised the method I followed.

Yours Respectfully,

D.F. MacKenzie M.D., M.M.

Dear Sir:

No. 51 - 0 - 13

In reply to your letter of June 1st, concerning the account of the Department of Public Health, Halifax, N.S. for diphtheria anti-toxin, etc.

When we sent you the account we were under quarantine, and it looked as if we would use all the anti-toxin we had secured from the Department of Public Health. Such was not the case, and the enclosed will show that we returned sixteen packages of anti-toxin to the Department at Halifax. The Doctor had given doses of 10,000 units to thirty five. That accounts for fifty one. The other six packages we have in cold storage.

It happened this way. One day the Doctor came over, and on first thought decided to give anti-toxin to those who had become ill since the previous visit. On second thought he decided to await the return of the nose and throat swabs which had been sent to Halifax. In the meantime, between the Doctor's thoughts, someone began opening the packages getting ready for the treatment. So the wrapping was destroyed on six packages. The Department at Halifax felt that they could not pass these on to anybody else, and we thought it wise to have some in store for a few months, so we kept the six packages.
However, if when the date for usage expires, and we have not used it, the Department of Public Health at Halifax will take it back. That date will be somewhere in 1941.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

October 16, 1939.

Reverend Sir:

It would appear that you will require a dental clinic of about three days, or two at the least. This will authorize expenditure for this purpose of not more than $90.00. It is believed that you will get the best value for the money by organizing a clinic at the school, and it is strongly recommended that you do so, if at all possible.

If necessary, you may say that the Department is providing this money from public funds, has only the pupils' interest in mind, and has found the cost higher and the amount of work less, when the children are taken to the dentist.

There is, presumably, no reason for haste, and it should be possible for Doctor McLeod to so arrange his time as to be able to do this work at the school.

These observations are based on a review of the work done last year at Doctor McLeod's office, and on wide experience elsewhere.

Yours truly,

November 21, 1939.

Reverend Sir:

In answer to your letter of October 19, regarding children needing their tonsils removed, I regret to inform you that funds available will only permit of four children being so treated.

You may select the four that most urgently require this treatment and make arrangements with Doctor Reid to have the operations carried out in Truro. The Truro Hospital is stated to have agreed to accept $3.00 for the first day, including the use of the operating room, and $1.50 a day thereafter. It may be that only one day's hospitalization will be necessary.

Very truly yours,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

Reverend J. P. Mackey,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
SHUBENACADIE, N.S.

PEM/NN
November 21, 1939.

EX'D.

Reverend Sir:

With reference to your letter of October 30 in which you stated that there are six children in the school in need of glasses, I have to advise you that if you still consider it to be essential you may take these children to Doctor Patton in Truro for examination of their eyes.

You may inform Doctor Patton that the Department will pay a fee of $4.00 for each examination, or $5.00 if drops are used.

If the doctor certifies any of these children to be in need of glasses, please obtain from him the prescription for the necessary glasses, and forward it to the Department here, and glasses will be supplied.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

Reverend J. P. Mackey,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
SHUBENACADIE, N.S.

Dear Sir:

We are enclosing the account of Doctor McLeod Dentist, for $90.00. This is the amount specified in your letter of October 16th, 1939.

The work began on November 14th, and continued on the following afternoons: November 15, 16, 17, 21, 22, 23, 24, 27, 28, 29, 30. Those requiring a general anesthetic were done by Doctor McLeod, in co-operation with Doctor MacInnis, on Saturday, December 2nd. Every child in the school was examined, and we are enclosing a list of those who had work done, a total of 49 fillings, 95 extractions, and six who had from five to eight extractions each.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Reference Your Letter January 4, Nancy Lampquin, Shubenacadie Indian Residential School.

The Department has received a copy of your report to Doctor MacInnis re Nancy Lampquin, an Indian girl from the residential school at Shubenacadie. Yours truly,

January 31, 1940

EXD.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a requisition from you and Father Mackey for 12 ampules of Mepharson for use in the Residential School.

In almost every province, the Provincial Health authorities are supplying this free to physicians for treatment of our Indians. Arsenicals are supplied free of charge to the Provincial Health authorities by the Department of Pensions and National Health of the Federal Government. No doubt if you request these materials from the Provincial Authorities, with this explanation, they will supply them as is being done in other provinces. If you should experience any difficulty in obtaining your supply, please communicate with the Department.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes
Secretary

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find form for Admission to Hospital and Sanatorium for the case of Jean Smith.

This girl has been running a temperature for two weeks or more, and today we received word from the Department of Public Health that she is an active T.B. case. A month or so ago, this girl along with the others, was X-Rayed and according to this report, she is an outstanding case. Will you please give the necessary permission to have her placed in the Sanatorium at Kentville?

We made application to the Sanatorium some time ago for Nancy Lampquin and received word from there that she would be admitted as soon as there was a vacancy. Halifax, March 2nd, 1928

Dear Sir:

In regard to the purchase of cows (for proposed Indian school at Shubenacadie) I might remind you that those on the Gay farm have not been tested for T.B. They will probably have the test completed within the next month. Should any of them re-act then there will be considerable work and expense in having done those things that are required by law. There have been quite a number of re-actors in and around that district.

J. P. MacKay.
Ottawa, March 6, 1928.

Reverend Sir:

With further reference to your letter of the 2nd instant, I have to inform you that the Department will consider the purchase of cows for the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School, after we have received a report following tuberculin test of the animals on the Gay farm. I take it that not more than one cow is required immediately and it will be timely to consider the purchase of a milch herd for the school pupils and staff some months from now. When you have received the report on the cows at present on the property, you might let me know the results. The Department will ask you to cooperate in the matter of the purchase of a milch herd.

You should let me know without delay what work horses and agricultural machinery will be required for the working of the farm this year. You might indicate if any of the equipment owned by Mr. Gay would be suitable and let me have, also, prices on new equipment of the kind required. I have to request that, in your present deliberations, you give consideration only to the stock and agricultural machinery that are necessary for the spring and summer of this year.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. Mackenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.
Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of March 6th, no. 51-0-14, I beg to say that concerning the tuberculous test of the cow, we have acted. You know that now they will have to clean up, removing all manure etc., etc. The question is now, who is to do that cleaning? From what they said yesterday they would rather lose the compensation for the cow than have the expense and work of cleaning up. It looks to me as if they have the advantage, for the barns must be cleaned sometime and the manure should go this way or the fields. However, I think the following scheme will work out. For the good of the farm the manure should be on the land now. If the Department could see their way clear to allow Wallace Roy, four-fifty a day, for putting out manure, then I feel that he could be induced, since he has now little else to do, to do the necessary cleaning in the

Dear Mr. Ilsley:

Accounts have been received, covering the cost of the purchase of a team of horses and a cow for the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School. These animals were purchased by Dr. P. A. Gough, Veterinary Surgeon, of Halifax. The horses were obtained from B. B. Fulmer and the price charged was $525. The cow was obtained from R. L. Parker at $150. It was considered that these prices are somewhat excessive, and the Department of Agriculture was requested to have the representative of its branch in the Maritime Provinces inspect these animals and place a valuation on them. I enclose, for your information, copy of the Inspector's report. Both parties have refused to accept the valuation made by the Department of Agriculture's representative and request payment at the amount approved by Dr. Gough.

I am somewhat in a quandary regarding the matter. We asked Dr. Gough to make purchase and he fixed the price; but it is rather difficult for us to pay the account, when we have a report that the prices are anything but fair and reasonable. I well know your wish that business arrangements should be carried out in an economical manner, so I thought I would let you know our difficulty.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Regarding the horses and cow that were purchased at Shubenacadie, I have seen Dr. Gough and asked him to explain to me the prices paid. He says that the cow is well worth $150.00; in fact, that Burchell Fulmer is willing to take her at this price if the Department does not want her.

As to the horses, he says that these horses are a good sound team, weighing thirty two hundred pounds, and that $525 is a fair price in view of present values. He cited instances of teams which have recently been sold in this Province for $600.00, stating that this had been the price paid at Liverpool where construction work is going on in connection with the erection of a paper mill. To-day I was told by a client who was discussing the general price of horses that he had heard of a good team having been sold for $600.00.

If these facts are correct I think it would be advisable to pay for the horses and cow without any further objection. Delivery has been taken of the horses and cow, and our own veterinary, Dr. Gough, approved of the price and it would appear to me that the Government is obliged to pay for them in any event. However, as I told you, I certainly do not want excessive prices
paid, and probably the action taken by the Department will be beneficial in this way that it will show any other persons that the Department is fully alive to prices that are being paid and watching each transaction closely.

Will you kindly let me know whether you will proceed on the foregoing advice.

Yours Truly,

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL, SHUBENACADIE, N. S.,
dated November 15, 1929.

Original on 51-0-15.

Have been making inquiries about cows and I believe it is a hopeless proposition to buy any kind of a decent cow at a reasonable price. The prices in the locality are more extreme than they were a year ago. Could you purchase them through the Dept. of Agriculture and ship them down here?
Ottawa, December 2, 1929.

Rev. J. P. Mackey,
Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N.S.

Further reference your letter fifteenth do you believe milk cows could be purchased locally if Mr. Archibald of Truro assisted you.

A. F. MacKENZIE.

Ck. Dept. I. A.
Ottawa, December 2, 1929.

Rev. J. P. Mackey,
Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N. S.

Further reference your letter fifteenth do you believe milk cows could be purchased locally if Mr. Archibald of Truro assisted you.

A. F. MacKenzie.

Chg. Dept. I. A.
Indian Residential School

Shubenacadie, N.S.
Dec. 4th. 1929.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your telegram of yesterday, I got in touch with Mr. C.A. Archibald, Dominion Live Stock representative and he said that he could get the cows locally. By that I think he means in the province, certainly not in the county of Hants. So we will have a look around and let you know all particulars before any purchase is made. I think that we should have about fifteen or sixteen milch cows, with four or five young stock, also a good bull. We would be able to handle them here early in January.

Yours very truly,

Mr. A.F. MacKenzie
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa, December 7, 1929.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th instant, with reference to the purchase of a milk herd for the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School. I note that Mr. C. A. Archibald, Dominion Live Stock representative, is hopeful that suitable animals can be secured locally. Please thank him for his cooperation, and, as soon as possible, forward his recommendations, with your comments. Authority to complete arrangements, if satisfactory, will then be directed to you. The Department agrees that 15 milch cows, 4 or 5 heifers and one bull are required.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. J. P. Mackey,
Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie,
N. S.
"I was out through the Shubenacadie district yesterday looking over some of the herds. Father MacKey advised me that the member for Hants County was very anxious to have the purchasing done in Hants County. I assured him that it would be very difficult for them to secure in any one county a herd of cattle that would be representative or good enough for an institution and as he had been in comparison to other the week previous who had been paying as high as $125.00 for pretty ordinary grades, he agreed with me.

We discussed the situation pretty thoroughly and while I can see his viewpoint of submitting prices to the Department at Ottawa and waiting for their acceptance, it is going to make it very difficult to secure the cattle. It will also be considerably more expensive as no one can buy economically in that way. In other words if we can go into a stable ready to buy and pin a man down to the actual value of the stock he is offering and have the sale slip signed there and then, we know just what we are doing. But as these cattle are to be bought subject to delivery sometime in January, as soon as the stable is complete, unless we tie the breeders up in some way it is almost unreasonable to ask them to hold their cattle should another buyer come in.

I know that you would want us to secure a representative herd, well up to the standard of whatever breed they were, or you would very much rather we did not touch the selection in any way. If you can get the officer in charge of the Indian Department and have this straightened out with a distinct understanding as to the maximum price they are willing to pay it would help the work greatly. The other questions, such as buying out of accredited herds, dates of calving, ages, etc. I took up with Father MacKey and the only thing I would like to have now is a distinct ruling on prices.

I might say that I assured Father MacKey that it would be a difficult achievement to secure the whole herd in Nova Scotia and we might be forced to go across to Prince Edward Island for a few head."
December 9, 1929.

Re purchase of cattle for school at Shubenacadie

Dear Sir:

Referring to my telephone conversation of this morning with Mr. Ferrier, I am now enclosing extract from letter received from Mr. C. A. Archibald, representative of my Division at Truro, Nova Scotia, who has been asked to assist Father MacKey in the purchase of cattle for the Indian School at Shubenacadie.

You will note that Mr. Archibald feels that it will be very difficult to secure satisfactory values if it is necessary to submit prices to Ottawa before closing any transactions and asks whether it would be possible to allow Father MacKey more latitude in this respect.

I infer from correspondence received from Mr. Archibald on this subject that in any discussions which he has had with Father MacKey he has understood that the purchase of only pure bred Ayrshires is contemplated. I understand from Mr. Ferrier that your Department is not particularly interested in the establishment of a breeding herd at Shubenacadie and that the primary consideration is the securing of cattle to supply milk for the institution. In that event, it might be better business to endeavour to secure the best grade cows obtainable than to pay extra money for registered cattle.

I would suggest the desirability of having the decision of your Department on this point made clear to Mr. Archibald through Father MacKey before any purchasing is undertaken.

Yours faithfully,

R. S. Hamer,
Chief of Cattle Division.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

MK Enc.
Ottawa, December 9, 1929.

Reverend Sir:

With further reference to your letter of the 4th and to my reply of the 7th instant, concerning a milch herd for the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School, I have now to inform you that the Department is considering placing the purchase entirely in the hands of Mr. C. A. Archibald, Dominion Live Stock representative, at Truro. I will write to you in a few days, giving final instructions. As you have been informed, the Department believes that 15 milch cows, 4 or 5 heifers and one bull are required.

I note your preference for the Ayrshire breed, and I now write to state that the Department does not consider it necessary to limit the selection to purebred, registered animals only. It is possible that grade cows would be suitable, and you might get more beef from the male animals and old cows that are killed. Of course, only accredited herds or tuberculin tested cows should be considered. I will write in a few days, giving final instructions.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. J. P. Mackey,
Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N. S.
Ottawa, December 10, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, with reference to the purchase of cattle for the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School. I wish to thank you for your cooperation and to state that I shall write in a few days, requesting your assistance. Your local representative's suggestions are now receiving consideration.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

R. S. Hamer, Esq.,
Chief Cattle Division,
Dominion Live Stock Branch,
Dept. of Agriculture,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, December 17, 1929.

Reverend Sir:

With reference to my letter of the 9th instant, concerning a milk herd for the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School, I have now to state that the Department has placed the purchase entirely with the Dominion Live Stock Branch. I am enclosing copy of my letter of today's date to the Chief of the Cattle Division. If Mr. Archibald wishes you to cooperate with him, you will of course do so. I am sure that he will meet your wishes as far as possible, but it is distinctly understood that the Live Stock Branch will have a free hand in the matter. It is only fair that this arrangement be made, if we are asking them to make the purchase for us.

ENCL.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. J. P. Mackey,
Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie,
N. S.
Ottawa, December 17, 1929.

Sir:

With further reference to your letter of the 9th and to my reply of the 10th instant, I have now to request your Branch to select and purchase a milch herd for the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School. Selection is not limited to herds in Hants County, if better satisfaction can be secured elsewhere; but I should be grateful if you would instruct Mr. Archibald to give the preference to dealers in the federal constituency in which the school is located.

There is required 15 milch cows, 5 heifers and one bull. The Rev. Principal prefers the Ayrshire breed, but I do not wish to dictate in this connection, as the matter will be left entirely with your Branch. The Department does not consider it necessary to limit the selection to pure-bred or registered animals only. It is possible that grade cows would be suitable and, of course, less expensive. I know you will consider only accredited herds or tuberculin tested animals.

This Department will be very grateful if you will give the necessary instructions to Mr. Archibald at your earliest convenience. If your office will forward the accounts, in duplicate, certified by Mr. Archibald, they will be paid. The question of price will be left entirely with you.

Thanking you for your cooperation,

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

R. S. Hamer, Esq.,
Chief Cattle Division,
Dominion Live Stock Branch,
Dept. of Agriculture, Ottawa, Ont.
Dear Sir;

Replying to your letter of December 17th I would state that as requested I am now arranging with Mr. Archibald to select and purchase a milch herd for the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School. I have forwarded copy of your letter to Mr. Archibald, in order that he may be fully familiar with the general conditions which your Department wishes observed in the handling of this order, and trust that in view of the very free hand which you have allowed him, Mr. Archibald will be able to secure cattle which will give you every satisfaction.

Yours faithfully,

R. S. Hamer,
Mr. A. F. MacKenzie, Chief of Cattle Division.
Acting Asst. Deputy & Sec'y,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

G.E.O.

Shubenacadie, N.S.

April 8th, 1930.

Dear Sir:

Would like very much to trade in my Chev. car for a Buick No. 47 model. I have made inquiries from three dealers and the best offer is my car and thirteen hundred and seventy dollars. With such a car I think that I would be able to get at least four years service.

In case that you would not feel like paying the difference between the cars might I remind you that I have been using my own car for the past two years in the interests of the School and the Dept. of Indian Affairs. In that time I have gone thirteen thousand miles, and the actual charge to the Dept. for the car is less than one hundred and twenty dollars. If I had been allowed the usual ten or twelve cents a mile you can easily see the difference. The fact is that I have been paying the charges for the car and not asking the Dept. to pay the most of them.

If I may have the new car I would like to know soon as I have not registered the Chev. for this year. The Buick model 47 sells here for $1940.00.

Yours very truly,

A.F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Dear Sir:

We beg to inform you that Joyce McDonald, No. 0185, 7 years old last May, died yesterday morning, October 26th.

This child came to the school from Cambridge, N.S., during the first week of September. She was not strong and spent some days of that month in bed, suffering from a cold. When Doctor MacInnis examined for tonsils, this name was on the list for tonsillectomy. On October 10th, we took eight children, six girls and two boys, including this child, to the Halifax Infirmary for the operation. They were all examined by Doctor Arthur Murphy that evening. Two were rejected, one having a cold and the other a slight throat infection. It appears that the Doctor was dubious about Joyce McDonald, for he had her chest examined. The next morning, he had the X-Ray report, and said that she would be done. The two who were rejected we took back to the school on Tuesday morning. The other six were done before noon of that day, the four girls first, and the two boys last. They all came through in good condition, and were discharged on Thursday morning, the 13th. We took them back to the school that afternoon, which by the way, was a bright warm day. On arrival, they were all put to bed immediately. This Joyce McDonald was as well as any, except for a slight cough. The weather being fine and warm, all except this child, were up and around Friday, but Joyce McDonald was kept in bed. The cough became worse, and Doctor MacInnis was called to see her on Saturday, Oct. 15th. By Tuesday the Doctor decided that she had pneumonia. We hope to have a statement from the Doctor soon, as to whether it was aspirated, septic, bronchial pneumonia, or abscess of the lung.
To the question of removing her to the hospital, the Doctor considered that she was too ill. So we had a graduate nurse brought in for night duty, and our staff nurse did day duty. The Doctor considered it advisable to have an oxygen tank, so we got that also. We informed the mother and she came here on Thursday, the 21st. She seemed quite satisfied that everything that could be done was being done for the child.

In conversation with the mother we were informed that the child has had a bronchial condition since she was a baby, also that the father of the child was considered by the Department as a white man, and that they were not receiving any relief from the Department. If that is true, then Mr. Simney, the Agent for Kentville, should have known that the child was not eligible for the school. However, that is a small matter now.

We hope to have the report of Doctor McNutt to enclose in this letter.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Dear Doctor: RE: JAMES PAUL

This Indian boy was admitted November 3rd with a cough and cold.

Examination of the Respiratory System showed dyspnea present with impaired resonance, rough breath sounds with coarse, moist rales all over the chest. X-ray showed the changes characteristic of Millary Tuberculosis. He ran a temperature daily up to 102 with pulse up to 140 and respirations 40 to 50. Condition became much worse after a few days in Hospital and he expired on November 13th, at 12:50 a.m. Two specimens of sputum had been negative for tubercle bacilli.

Yours truly,

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Dear Sir:

With regard to the tragic death of Mary Ginnish, No. 0116, and Doris Atquin, No. 0174, we beg to submit the following report:

It has been customary from the time the school was opened for the children to go berry picking. The season for berries would begin late in June, and end late in August. As usual the children, especially the girls, have been picking berries this year. The group of about twenty leave together, but later break up into small groups, and go to different places but in the same locality. The result is that they do not come home in one group but in small groups of two, three, and four.

On August the 12th, eighteen girls left after dinner for raspberries and blueberries. By four o'clock, some were home, and others could be seen coming. Rita Pietou, coming with two others, took the path near the lake, and saw two pairs of scampers, and two cans of berries, which she recognized as belonging to Mary Ginnish and Doris Atquin. She hurried home to tell Sister Mary Leonard, Supervisor for the girls. Sister Mary Leonard asked Sister Beatrice if she would go to the lake, but a minute later realizing the possibilities, called Mr. McLeod to drive her over. She saw no signs of the girls, but the punt was overturned out some twenty-five or thirty feet out from the shore.

For myself, I was busy at the time all this was going on, as we had Miss Black, Supervisor of Handicrafts for the
Province, and Mrs. Deichman, Pottery Expert from N.B., along with two other young women.

When Sister Mary Leonard returned from the lake about five o'clock, she immediately told me what the situation was. To me it seemed hopeless, and the only thing to do was to recover the bodies as soon as we could. Mr. Rice, Mr. McKinnon, and Mr. Baker of the R.C.M.P. and myself were soon at the lake. Mr. Parker, Mr. McLeod, and Mr. Crowell soon arrived with a boat. All the available men in the village were soon there, with boats, grappling irons, etc.

By this time it was about six o'clock. Grappling operations from two boats were patrolling what we figured would be the possible place of the accident. About eight o'clock the body of Doris Atquin was brought to the surface, and within five minutes, that of Mary Ginnish.

We wanted to have an inquest right there, and one member of the R.C.M.P. told us that the Coroner would be along. After waiting for some time the Corporal in charge of the R.C.M.P. detachment here said that the coroner decided there was no need of the inquest, according to the laws of this Province, therefore, he would hold none, but that he would come the following morning to make out the necessary papers.

We then passed the bodies over to the Undertaker, H.M. Ettinger, wired the Secretary, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Dept. of Indian Affairs, also Agent Whelan at Fredericton, and Acting Agent Hudson at Richibucto, informing them of the accident, and asking them to inform the parents and relatives. Doris Atquin came from North Devon, N.B., and Mary Ginnish from Burnt Church, N.B. We also informed the Agents that the bodies would be sent on the Maritime Express Friday afternoon. Then the following morning we got in touch with the two Sisters of Mary Ginnish, both ex-pupils, and had them accompany the bodies as far as Newcastle.

Yesterday the bodies were returned to the school between 11.30 and twelve o'clock A.M. We, all the children and sisters, accompanied the bodies to the train, Maritime Express, at 4.30. Letters were sent to Mr. John Ginnish, father of Mary, as her mother is dead, and to Virginia Atquin, sister of Doris, whose mother and father are both dead.
Corporal Cheesman took statements from Clara Julian, Rita Picou, Sister Mar. Leonard, and myself. If I can obtain a copy of these statements, they will be enclosed in this letter. If not, then we will try and give you the substance of them. We hope to have a copy by Monday, August 16th.

I do not think it necessary to go into detail concerning the warnings given both, with regard to the lake, and the river.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Dear Father Mackey:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of August 14, in which you submit information with respect to the tragic death of Mary Ginnish, No. 0118, and Doris Atquin, No. 0174.

It is scarcely necessary to state that the news of this tragic accident, reported by you to the Department by telegram on August 13, came as a great shock to the officials of this Division. It would appear that accidents such as this occur from time to time, despite the attempts made by Principals in charge of our residential schools to prevent them.

I have just learned that Mr. Phelan is likely to visit Halifax early in September and I have already discussed with him the advisability of visiting your school at that time. I am anxious that Mr. Phelan and you should discuss, at the time of his visit, the supervision of these girls who may be disposed to go out with berry-picking parties in the future. It is just possible that an arrangement might be reached whereby these girls would not be permitted to break up into small groups. In any event this matter is one that can be discussed more profitably and more helpfully by Mr. Phelan when he meets you than by lengthy correspondence.

If you have an opportunity to do so, it would be appreciated if you would extend to the relatives of these girls the sincere sympathy of the officials of the Welfare & Training Division.

Yours truly,

"Crude" Boat, Left At Lake,
Death Trap For Two Girls

SHUBNACADAY, Aug. 18—An overturned boat on a lake shore provided an instrument of tragedy yesterday when a supposed sailing expedition swept away the lives of Mary Ginish and Doris Atquin, pupils at the nearby Indian Reservation School.

Gave Alarm

The two girls, who were both about 15 years of age, were taking part in a summer expedition carried on daily at the school. Under the guidance of a Sister of Mercy, the girls are taught the woods where they scatter in different directions to gather berries and return to the school when they have succeeded in filling them.

About noon yesterday afternoon returning homeward saw the two girls' shoes and pails on the shores of Clyde Lake. The teacher immediately hurried to the school and told the sisters. Fr. J. J. "Crude" Boat, Left At Lake,
Death Trap For Two Girls

SHUBENACADIE, Aug. 13—An untended boat on a lake shore proved an instrument of tragedy yesterday, when a supposed sailing expedition swept away the lives of Mary Ginish and Doris Atquin, pupils at the nearby Indian Reservation School.

Gave Alarm

The two girls, who were both about 15 years of age, were taking part in a berrying expedition directed by their school teacher. Under the guidance of a Sister of Charity, the pupils are taken to the woods, where they follow different directions to fill their pails and to return to the school when they have succeeded in filling them.

About 4:30 o'clock children returning home reported seeing girls' shoes and pails on the shores of Clyde's Lake. They immediately hurried to the scene and informed sisters. Father J. P. Mackie, who directs the school notified the village of the incident and the residents turned out in aid of the search. C. Rive, chief of police, B. Macdonald, his assistant, and representatives of the R.C.M.P., were the first to arrive at the scene.

The bodies of the girls were recovered at about 9:30 in the evening. An overturned boat near the shore led the searchers to assume that the children had been tempted to go for a sail. Apparently, the boat, which one of the girls described as "cruelly" constructed, got among the trees and capsized, drowning the two children in the water. It is believed that neither of the victims was able to swim.

Boats Forwarded To Homes

It is thought that the girls could not have been missing more than half an hour before the alarm was given. The gally berry pails had been filled, and teachers said this could hardly be done before 4 o'clock.

The Reservation school is supplied with water from the lake.

The bodies of the victims are being forwarded today to their homes in New Brunswick. Doris Atquin was a native of North Devon and Mary Ginish of Burnt Church, in that province.

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of

of the Shuswap Indian Residential School at Shuswap Lake,

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

B. STATEMENT OF THE PHYSICIAN WHO ATTENDED THE DECEASED PUPIL

I attended Colin Bernard from Oct 15th/43 to Oct 19th/43. The immediate cause of death was absence in throat complicated with diphtheria.

The contributory cause of death was scarlet fever, tonsillitis, and inflammation of throat and tonsils.

Do you consider that the Principal of the School, and the members of the School staff exercised reasonable care and judgment in regard to the illness and death of this pupil? Yes.

Did they follow out your professional instructions? Yes.

If in either respect, you consider them to have been at fault, it is required that you express your carefully considered views as follows:

Even with an interferer he did not complain of sore throat. Due to the swollen condition of a year old child and an old case of "lance" it was impossible to get a good look at his throat or to swallow with ease. So I gave him 20,000 units of antitoxin at this time. I first gave him and took the throat. Then on Oct 15th I got the antitoxin again on Oct 19th. During this interval he had run a normal temperature (about) had taken liquids and solids on day of sudden death. There was no smell of diphtheria from his throat. I saw him daily. His condition improved. The slight temperature went down. The abscess broke on the night of Oct 18th the swelling receded in the throat.

M.D.

P.S. After getting a positive report for diphtheria on the 19th I went back for daily call and to examine the throat carefully. I found the tonsils with some spots on them only. He sat up in bed frame to look in his throat. After the first look he shook his teeth as usual. The sister helped coax him to open his mouth but failed. So rather than force him to hurt himself I decided to give more antitoxin to be safe.

SUMMARY OF ACTIVITIES AT THE SHUBENACADIE INDIAN AGENCY FROM OCTOBER - 43 TO JANUARY - 44.

On December 14th this centralization project lost, to a great extent, the services of a good friend and an experienced adviser. Rev. Fr. Mackie, principal of the Residential School since its founding, was forced by recurring illnesses to relinquish his place as Principal and revert again to light parish work. Practically all summer his stomach condition bothered him and was aggravated, I believe, by a series of regrettable occurrences. First blow was the accidental drowning of two young girls of the school. He felt this very keenly. Next came an epidemic of diphtheria at the school, then three runaway attempts in extremely cold weather by children who were ill clothed for the temperatures we were then experiencing. Finally just home from the hospital he was unfortunate enough to meet the doctor, on the doorstep of the school, coming out with a child on a stretcher. The idea which had been milling in his mind for some time suddenly became a decision and he forthwith sent in his resignation. We here at the agency and all of Shubenacadie were sorry to see him go, but we feel that due to his health the step he took was necessary. It is well known that the work of the present successor or any other in fact, will be made much easier because of the good will and respect enjoyed in this community by Fr. Mackie.

His successor, Fr. Brown, was my parish priest in Kentville and served for a time in Enfield 14 miles from here. His knowledge of the Cambridge Indians is extensive and it is well known that he always had a liking for what he calls "the poor Indian". He is a favourite of all children regardless of color or creed and in my opinion will have more trouble with ration coupons and pedigrees than managing 160 children. He too is a backer of the centralization idea and will do all in his power to help and speed the project along.

H.C. Rice,
Indian Agent.

Arsenault teacher had resigned the position, and informing it also that there were two applicants Mr. Casimir Poirier who has taught there 8 years and a certain Mr. Gould who is in the States and that his father had applied for him, and that he was recommended by Hon. Moreover this young man has taught only six months and could not find a school, he has been away over three years consequently his licence is not valid now. MEMORANDUM.

To The Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

Sir,

I have the honor to report that in compliance with the instructions of the Department I visited the Lennox Island reserve on the 2nd instant, accompanied by the local Agent, Mr. J. O. Arsenault.

SCHOOL

The school is a frame building 26 x 20 feet, with 13 ft. posts, on a red sandstone foundation, erected in 1898. It is in good condition, and in all respects will compare favorably with the rural white school buildings on Prince Edward Island. It is centrally situated. There is about an acre of land in connection with the school for play-grounds &c., part of which is covered with a growth of young spruce.

The class-room is 20 x 20 feet, with a cloak-room at the entrance, extending the full width of the building. There are three windows on each side of the class-room, and it is well lighted. I considered the room small for the number of children present. The walls and ceiling are sheeted with matched boards, and the room is warm and comfortable in winter.

They have the old-fashioned wooden desks, arranged in two rows, the length of the room. The desks were in good repair. The room itself was neat and clean, and is swept each day and scrubbed frequently. There is no cupboard for school
school supplies, but the teacher has a large desk where all supplies not in use are kept locked up.

A new blackboard is badly needed, as the one at present in use is too small, being only 3 x 6 ft. I would beg to suggest that a hyloplate blackboard be furnished this school 16 x 4 ft., if supplied by the manufacturer in that size. This, I think, should be supplied at once. There were 3 maps on the walls, one of the Dominion, one of P.E. Island, and one of the World. A few frame pictures would relieve the barren look and brighten the school-room. The windows should also be provided with roller blinds. Some school material was required. The teacher will make out a requisition and forward through the Agent in the usual way.

The outside steps had completely rotted away. The Chief told me he would have new ones built at once, there being lumber near the school which he could use for the purpose.

The school is heated by a large stove, burning wood, and the ex-Chief told me it was no trouble to keep it warm during winter. There is a scarcity of wood on the reserve, but the Agent always attends to the supply of fuel for the school.

There were 24 children in attendance the date of my visit, and the register showed an enrollment of 31; viz., 14 boys and 17 girls, being all the children of school age at that time living on the reserve. The children looked clean and in most cases fairly well dressed.

The teacher, John J. Sark, is a son of the ex-Chief, and was but recently appointed. He holds a 3rd class P.E. Island teacher's license. He is bright and intelligent.
intelligent-looking and appeared interested in the work. I heard him examine some of the children in a lesson in reading. They spoke distinctly, and when questioned about the lesson, the majority of them could answer correctly. The children are all young, and the teaching is therefore very elementary.

I told the teacher to use English altogether and to have the children speak it at all times. All the Indians on the reserve speak and understand English. I impressed upon the teacher the need of getting about among the parents; and at all times when a pupil was absent to find out why, and to induce the parents to send them regularly. The Chief promised to help him in this respect.

The teacher understands that his permanent appointment depends upon his own efforts in making a success of the work. I told him it was "up to him" to make good as he has every chance to make this one of the best Indian Schools in the Maritime Provinces. The children are all within easy distance of the school, the farthest away being 1½ miles.

I have no doubt that a great inducement towards their regular attendance during the winter would be the providing of a mid-day meal of biscuits, tea, &c. The Agent agreed with me that this would be a good idea, and the expense need not be large. The teacher could have charge of the supplies and prepare the lunch.

The school building should be whitewashed outside and the roof painted next Spring, and it would then be the equal in appearance and in neatness of any rural school in Prince Edward Island.

MEMORANDUM.

I am in receipt of a personal letter from Mr. John J. Sark, teacher of the Lennox Island school, in which he requests me to place before the Department the matter of his receiving an increase in salary.

He has been in charge of this school for the past year and is at present receiving a salary of $300.00 per annum. When he took charge the attendance was only 20 with an average of 12. He has attained an attendance of 45 with an average of 22. The Public School Inspector for Prince County, P.E.I., Mr. Boulter, on the occasion of his last visit to the school, reports as follows: "I was very favourably impressed with Mr. Sark's method of teaching and with his manner in the school-room. He is very energetic, commands the respect of his pupils and seeks to improve them." Mr. Agent Arsenault on a recent visit reports on Mr. Sark's work as follows: "Very good progress is made since the last visit. The teacher is well liked by the children and parents. He is doing remarkably well."
Mr. Sark is an Indian and holds a Third Class Teacher's License from the Board of Education of Prince Edward Island. As an encouragement to him in his work I would beg to suggest that he receive an increase of $50.00 from the 1st of July, last, making his salary $350.00 per annum.

Dear Mrs. Sutherland,

Yesterday was the last day of our school. We had a very successful examination Thursday. I gave some twenty prizes to the children. Nobody else would give them any prizes. They were made up of small reading books and toys etc.

Two teachers were present from the
other side. Mr. John Brown from Grand River and Mr. Raymond of Port Hill.

I am still having that notion of going back to College. I am thinking of going back (to College) year after next. I did not pay for the debt at the College and as I said before I want to lay something by for my future education.

Would you be so kind enough to ask for me the increase of my salary again for the coming year 1911-12?
I know you Mr. Sutherland you got it increased last year and if it can be done this year you will do it.

I'm glad it will be when it shall be increased.

I have worked harder than ever before and you can rely on me I'll do my very best although there is a slight chance of improvement, if the Dept. will increase it Fifty Dollars more.

When you were here
Sept. 2nd, 1919 you said if I keep up my work average and work well the Dept. will something bring down salary. And they did bring joy. I had an average of 82 at that time but now I have an average of 261295.

You will learn better from my return the number of pupils etc. I have just finished today.

Hoping you will kindly advise the Department and they will grant me the increase.

Yours very respectfully,

John [signature]

Sir,

I think that considering all the circumstances of the report which Thadly Knockwood sends the department about John J. Sark that it is better for Agnes Knockwood not to attend the school at Bonnox Island. I enclose the reasons which the teacher gave me for not wishing to have her continue to attend school. I considered Agnes a good girl but I may have been mistaken. The young man with whom she kept company was not a very good man. Barney Francis is his name. He is the champion one mile runner of Canada and has no settled occupation. He and his brother have been drinking and fighting and seemed to be incited by Thadly Knockwood tho I have no positive proof of it.

I can state that before the war Thadly was generally considered a bad Indian. But since his return he has had great sympathy on account of his very serious wounds which have affected his hearing. He is now in the Camp Hill hospital for treatment. He was arrested for using abusive language to the English wife of John J. Sark. He was taken to Summerside convicted and sentenced to a fine of ten dollars and costs. He then took one of the bad fits which follow great vexation or excitement and then was sent first to the Sh'Town Hospital and afterwards to the Camp Hill. I have been sent for several times to go to the house and try to save the life of his wife and family. He has revolvers and I got one from him at one time. Of course he is docile and friendly with me but seems to be plotting against those whom he considers his enemies. Of course he is no doubt more responsible for his acts but that does not make it easier for those whom he does not like. Those who do good turns for him are often the first to feel his resentment.

His statement about one half of the Indian children not going to school on account of the teacher drinking &c is not correct. The statement given in the enclosed letter of the teacher's is more in accordance with the facts. I do not consider John J. Sark intemperate tho he is not a total abstainer. Anthony Mitchell told me that John had been drinking several times but he did not do so on duty or to give offence to any one. As the girl Agnes Knockwood will be 19 years of age in a few days and the teacher is evidently afraid of a frame up against him in any way it is better for the girl not to attend school. I consider Mr Sark is doing excellent work as is born out by the different inspectors.

The best proof of the unreliability of any charge from Thadly Knockwood is that at the trial in Summerside he had witnesses to testify that he was always agreeable at home and on good terms with all his neighbors. While I had been repeatedly sent for by his wife and family to save their lives. Once in particular he almost choked his wife to death and it took his son-in-law and brother-in-law to protect her and family till they could get him to the hospital. All things considered I do not think his word should be taken or that Agnes should be admitted to the school.

Mr Whear consulted with me and I felt obliged to give my honest opinion of Isaac Peters and the reasons why his word should not be taken. He was in jail in Summerside a few years ago for robbery. He way laid other Indians returning from the harvest excursion to the Canadian west at Moncton N.B. and relieved them of their money. One of them followed up the case and had him arrested and locked in the Summerside jail for three months. This fact having happened only a few years ago is fresh in the minds of everybody. The second charge against him is that Mr Peters brought the first still to Lennox Island and showed his son-in-law how to manufacture moonshine. This is commonly believed but I have no positive proof of the fact. Another charge I gave to Mr Whear was that Mr Peters made a false statement to the Vital Statistics branch in Charlottetown in getting the name of Patrick Peters recorded as being 21 years of age. Dear Sir:

Since I was requested to write to you by some of our people and gentlemen in Prince County, I humbly decided to do concerning the party and the accusation they sent you concerning my dismissal after serving our Department five years before the war and it will be ten years next April since the great war.

(From December 1914 till June 1918 I served our King and Country in that great conflict both in France and Belgium.)

During my service with the Department I hope and trust you have never found me dishonest or
or unethical in any way.

Your records show that there have been complaints made from time to time. I am sorry to say that she was who made those complaints is now in a mental hospital in Charlottetown.

My accusers in this case, kindly pardon me for writing about them, are men of an unreliable character etc.

I can truthfully say and take my oath that when I was assaulted on the 24th day of July during my holidays I was not drunk as the accusation goes or did strike Mrs. Bernard.

If Mrs. Bernard speaks the truth he will say the same.

We attacked me treacherously on the back of my head (from behind) jumped on top of me, bit my fingers, gnawed one so bad I had to go to the hospital the 13th day of August finally lost my fingers after two operations consequently could not open our school on the first day of September.
This is a hard blow on my family and character as I have just lost a finger and my hand is too crippled for any other work besides I have three children. The eldest is nine years old, the others are five and one and a half years.

If the report had been true I would not have written to our Department for fair-play.

It is only ten years ago since we fought for justice and fair-play—As a British subject, a returned soldier, for British fair-play and the execution as one asked would I ask too much to beg an investigation to be made by an impartial and disinterested party and to humbly beg our Department to reconsider their decision?

Your obedient servant,

John J. Sark

WORK OF INDIAN TEACHER PRAISED

John Sark, of Lennox Island, Gives Credit For Success to His English Wife, a War Bride

LENNOX ISLAND, P.E.I., Dec. 27—(C.P.)—John Sark renounced his hereditary title as Chief of the Micmac Indian reserve here when he answered the call of the Empire and overseas with the 24th Battery as a non-commissioned officer. But today, as teacher of the Micmac school, he is still chieftain to Indian youth.

During a recent conference visit to the Micmac colony off the north coast of Prince Edward Island, Miss Hilda W. Gillis, Inspector of Schools, reported: "The teacher is an outstanding athlete and musician. The pupils showed aptitude in the mechanics of reading, writing and other school subjects. The Micmac language is especially well taught in both Micmac and English."

"The teacher takes advantage of Carnegie Library facilities and is well versed in the principles of teaching. The Indian pupils are apparently slow to grasp ideas when presented in English but it is remarkable how quickly they acquire what they receive and how thoroughly their studies come home."

"Mr. Sark," the school inspector said, "has had a great experience in education. His method is satisfactory and commendable."

Happy is Mr. Sark living at the Reserve with his family and English wife, a war bride. His wife, Miss Edith Houghton at Dover Castle in England during the war. She was a volunteer nurse and Canadian artilleryman. War separated them for a time. They were married in December, 1915. Once the war ended she went to the front and the war bride returned to her duties ministering to the sick maimed.

In the Spring of 1917 a gun carriage was brought from France and ordered home to convalesce. In the Dunstan Sanatorium, Wilshere, P.E.I., she lay for weeks while her wife still behind the front line, carried on her work.

The Red Man had lost everything. Smashed in health, the future was bitter. The English woman took him "with the velocity of a hurricane through the lines of opposing teams when his own side was caught with St. Dunstan University's mighty football squad, was sapped.

Finally a letter came from the English girl saying she was coming to join him.

She helped her find her way to Dalton and walked into my presence unannounced. When I saw her standing there, I knew that her heart was the perfect heart—"Where you are, I should be," she said, "and where I am, you must be."

The doctors had told the Indian he would be an invalid for the rest of his life. But he decided to Sark, resuming the story in his own words, "we were more than husband and wife; our strength and I was able to take over the Micmac school at the Lennox Island Reservation.

In the eyes of his people his wife was a stranger and for a time unloved. But the purity of her nature, the unselfishness of her life and the sacrifices she made upon won their everlasting affection."

The English woman has adapted herself to the Micmac life and become a leading spirit in the community. They have five attractive children who attend attending the little school. They speak both Micmac and English. Their mother has never learned the Micmac tongue.

The war and the consequences of it continued the keen-eyed Indian woman, "but I have to thank God for the world helper that brought me the English girl and the children that now surround us."
EX'D.

Borden, P.E.I.

Dear SIR -

I have your letter dated July 22nd, File No. 57-1-1 together with the petition signed by some thirty-six Indians requesting a change in the School Teacher.

In reply I may say that I have had quite a number of complaints at different times regarding the way Mr. Sark "their teacher" punished the pupils. I have also checked Mr. Sark on punishing the pupils by keeping them in during recreation hours and he states that in many cases it has made them get their work done, which otherwise would not have been done. I have been informed by the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch that a petition, asking for the dismissal of this teacher, reached this Department on July 5th, last. In his report the Indian agent expressed the opinion that the complaints referred to in the petition were not at all serious and suggested that a letter should be sent forward to the teacher from the Department, asking him to be a little more considerate in his treatment of the pupils. The Department communicated with the teacher on August 18, 1938. In this letter the suggestion was made that the Indian agent and the teacher should call the Indian parents together at a public meeting and discuss fully the grievances enumerated in the petition sent forward to the Department. There is nothing on file, however, to indicate that this meeting has been held. It is our intention to communicate with the Indian agent and with the teacher again, asking them to take the steps necessary to call a meeting of the parents.

In addition to this, it is our intention to have the local school inspector send in a special report -

report on Mr. Sark's work and on the progress the pupils have been making in recent months. Dear Sir:

I hope you will pardon me writing to you on behalf of my husband John J. Sark, teacher of Lennox Island school. I read your letter so I am writing unknow to him.

It is not proper to write about myself, but to make things clear I must, so will you please pardon me for doing so.

I am an English woman, married John J., while nursing in England during the Great War. So I will try and give you a little light on what the petition is all about for dismissing my husband from the school which he has served for a good many years even before he went to fight for his country.
In the first place it is just Spite from some of the uneducated people and those that are always finding fault and trying to make mischief, with everything never satisfied and hard to please, especially when under the influence of drink and there is lots of it going on here right now. The other reason is that quite a lot of the children have been sent to the Residential School at Shubenacadie where they are kept in food and clothes and the parents are drawing the full supplies at home so that they can loaf around and have no bother and lots of them if they tried could make a good living for their family and they get good help from the Department. We have four of our own children going to school besides three others, and I know how those that are going to school are treated, in fact they always get the worst as an example to the other peoples; the parents say that they should not be kept in from recreation or punishment, as it causes the children to develop.
