Dear Sir:

Re grievance among Indians of Lennox Island and their school teacher, John J. Sark, immediately on receipt of copy of letter to J.J. Sark from the Dept., a meeting was called supposedly for the parents of the pupils attending school, and found that not only the parents attended this meeting, but the young unmarried men, and older married men whose children were attending Shubenacadie School, also married men who had no family.

After outlining the reason of the meeting and after receiving the assurance of the teacher to co-operate with the parents in coming to an amicable settlement, I took it upon myself to assure them that I would do everything possible to be of assistance. I even told them, if really necessary, I would visit the school twice monthly if my presence would bring the dispute to an end.

After discussing the matter for about two hours, and seeing that nothing definite could be arrived at, through a certain faction holding out against the teacher, I instructed John J. Sark to open the school at the beginning of the term.

I have since learned from the teacher that his strongest hold out is his own brother Jacob Sark, who is the Chief, and who appears to be influenced by Indians who have no children attending, and have really no say in the matter.

I understand that the Chief is going to visit the Dept. next week, and naturally he has to abide by whatever instructions the Dept. will give him.
Personally speaking, I can see no reason whatever for dissatisfaction with the present teacher's work since my appointment, except a matter of a little impatience, as cited in my letter of August 9th.

I was expecting from time to time that the children would be attending school at the re-opening of the term, as Mr. Sark the teacher gave me his assurance that he could and would, through a short space of time, mutually agree with the parents and get everything going smoothly.

Now, apparently the objective aimed at is to either send the children to Shubenacadie, which has now its full quota, or employ a white teacher. The latter would be impossible, as the only place for a white teacher to board would be at the present School teacher's home, and this of course would be resented by Sark, especially after receiving his dismissal.

I even suggested that John Sark's daughter Martha, who will be attending Prince of Wales College, will eventually succeed her father as school teacher, but they will not listen to this at all, which goes to show that the greater part of the grievance can be boiled down to one word "SPITE".

I trust after you have considered the facts as set forth in this letter, which I think I have made clear, that you can form a satisfactory solution.

I am enclosing a letter from J.J. Sark the teacher, which after perusal, you may kindly return same to me for my files.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I received your letters of the 18th and 26th, and I am very sorry I had not acknowledged them earlier but I left it in the hands of our Agent. In answer I beg to say as soon as I got your letter I went direct to Summerside to see Mr. MacDougall and arranged to see the parents' few days afterwards. The first met the parents of the children who were attending school. They told us they did not find any fault with the school or the teacher. Then all the parents of Lemnay Island met at the Hall. Our Agent tried to talk to them but they would not listen to reason. He told them that he was not taking my part but he could not very well recommend my dismissal as their grievances were not serious enough. He told them he would like to see me teach me more and all their grievances will be remedied.
All the agitation came from the parents who had not any children attending school. Parents with school children kept quiet. Finally Chief Jack Sack promised our Agent that the parents with school children would meet the following evening. Then they would give their effort to him.

And since the children had been tested for T.B., and found 57% of them workhouseable, they put the blame on our school teacher.

Chief Isaac Peters, Daniel Mitchell, Urban Mitchell, Joseph Knauthwood were the chief agitators. Isaac Peters has not any children to go to school, but just he and his wife. He gets an old age and Army pension and Government supplies come as some for Indians.

He told me the Department took his supplies away from him once but he wrote and got them back again. He is not a very good character.

Daniel & Urban are not married. Daniel served in the Army. After she was his first wife and an Attorney took him out of an English prison. A few years ago he was taken to a Mental Hospital in Charlottetown and kept there. Even since that he had a very shaky record.
Joseph Kootenay is married but does not live with his wife. He has no children. He is living with his mother who is getting a good pension. His mother two brothers and a sister are drawing Government supplies. He is well known by the R.C.M.P. and the jail.

This petition was drawn up and sent through offices and jailors. That is why an Indian in our Reserve does not get ahead. As soon as one is improving his house or his farm they all turn on him.

There are some who do not do any work. They are where they were years ago and they cannot bear to see others getting ahead.

I served under three Agents, three inspectors and they all gave me a good report and found my work to very high order.

One rain a shine winter or summer I have my school operating with the best I have in me. One year, in Father's time, all the schools were closed in P.E.I., but our humble schools. I am a Catholic not only by name, and it is through my sacred religion I want to serve my God honestly, to our Indian Department, to my fellowmen and to myself.
I passed two girls at the 8th grade with the four material I have here. Different text books show she measured in O.C. D.M. Both passed at Missoula College with honors and high marks. One is in University of Idaho College. I started teaching here with only $200 in 1907.

Why I found these complaints so hard to bear. In June 1937 & 1938 we had accomplished an enormous amount of work in our school. After all the work is completed they asked you dismissed in the school closed.

The children are anxious to go to school but I understand the parents to say they were expecting a letter from Ottawa. I was talking to Chief Jack's family. Asked him if the Department were to allow me to continue to teach would his children go. He answered yes and willingly. He only wished now that everything was settled.

The reason I asked him was this: When I asked the other families if their children were coming to school, their answers were: We do not find any fault with you or your school. When Chief Jack's children go they will all go. It seems that they do not want to listen to me. Last winter they had no school to hold.
their business meetings. Next morning I found a very rank and unhealthy odor, tobacco spit on the floor and walls. They even left a dog overnight. We visited our school. Our new Chief was good enough to get us a new stove. It was left in the porch. I asked Chief Jacobs as he is a Trust Officer and his wife Mrs. Anna Leck a janitor to get someone to put it up for the sake of our children. They did not do it. The stove was not put up till the month of January. The children were nearly finished with cold.

We had our new stove for eighteen days and the ghosts were turned out. They took their looks through windows.

His wife Anna Leck took our schoolroom home, our drinking pail used it for milk. She brought back it was soaked with thick milk. I took a mixture nearly two tons of coal. I suspected she janitors or her children taking it home as they had a key for the attic.

When they were burning the coal for the school from the snow they left about 50 lbs. under the shelf for their use.

When they were dismantling the old Tucker's house they used a good butcher for fuel.
Their 15-year-old girl knocked down a 6-year-old girl and kicked her.

Their 8-year-old girl did the same to a 4-year-old boy. Their 6-year-old boy was carrying newspapers and was in school, but they were his. The same boy used a dirty language. There was a lot of house-brewing and fighting going on the Reserve.

All this I reported to our chief, who is he is a chief, trust officer and also our agent every week. That is the only thing I remember ever being guilty of. Instead of Chief Jack taking something his children he kept them home from school instead of correcting his wife he took her part and turned against our family.

I have also reported them all to my agent. Some of their family are getting government supplies and double supplies and they are brewing beer getting drunk themselves and others too. Even women are in it.

I reported to our Agent and Chief but nothing has been done. Our Chief is encouraging them as he has been doing heavily all winter and I believe what's worse all the trouble and agitation about the weather for they know too much and our school. If we can only get him off he will go away.
As Corporal Lyons of the R.C.M.P. who was brought here for trouble, drinking and fighting, remarked: These people are not well treated by the Department. They are living on the fat of the land, they do not know how hard times or what a hard work means. If they were to go in want or earn their living they would not have so much time to make trouble. It is not true that all the parents want to break up their homes and start with their dear ones and send them to Shubenacadie school same as we do here in P.E.I. Island with our black faces.

Last year we had six families and nine children & schools. I visited them, met them and chatted with them. I was well received. They told me long and time again why I found no fault with me at our school. It is our Chief's hard work backed and guided by those few spectators.

When your first letter came I went to our representative for Prince E., A.C. MacLean Esq., and begged him to help me finish the term of 1938-1939. So by that time we will have some of our Residential attending P.W. College free with license.
Then we will have a change of a teacher every few years.

(Where other additional trouble comes in our school is reminding the students to sweep and dust the school, also and tidy up and have it scrubbed clean.)

I only hope and pray now that you kindly bear with me as there is so much to write about for explanation that you will be able to see it clear.

To have our school kept open and be good enough to let me finish the year. Only thing I am sorry now what I could not do any more work for our school—

If my people do not want good service done in our school as their minds are clouded and dimmed with apathy and jealousy I only pray that you and the Department will appreciate and do not try to discourage me in the efforts of a returned man 1914-18.

Would I ask too much if I beg you not to close our school or dismiss me as I always fought for honest justice and fair play and my best records from 1907?

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, November 7, 1935.

Memorandum:

DR. MCILL:

A petition has been received by the Department from a number of Indian residents of Prince Edward Island, asking that the children enrolled at the Lennox Island Indian Day School be transferred to the Shubenacadie Residential School, or, if such action were impossible at this time, that a new teacher be appointed to take charge of the Lennox Island School. This petition was received at the Department on July 21, 1935.

A letter dated July 22, 1935, was sent forward by this Branch to Mr. N. A. McDougall, Indian Agent, Summerside, P.E.I., asking him to make an investigation of the alleged grievances and to report to the Department.

Mr. McDougall, in his report dated August 9, states:

"I may say that I have had quite a number of complaints at different times regarding the way Mr. Sark, the teacher, punished the pupils. He is supposed to have made a practice of throwing up to the children of the school the wrongs their parents are doing and have done on the reserve - which is very childish. I have discussed this matter with Mr. Sark. He states that such reports are absolutely false. There is about the only complaint I have received and I feel that a letter from the Department to Mr. Sark, asking him to be a little more considerate with his pupils, would be all that is required. In conclusion I may state that any time I visited the Lennox Island School I found everything in order and the school well kept."

On August 13, 1935, a letter was sent to the teacher, in which the suggestion was made that he might be well advised to discuss the situation with the parents at a public meeting called for that purpose. The teacher did not reply to our communication of August 13, with the result that a second letter, dated September 30, was sent to him. A copy of this letter is attached. The teacher, in a lengthy communication dated October 5, explained that the delay in calling the meeting was due to misunderstanding which had developed - the teacher being of the opinion that the Agent, and not himself, should take the initiative in calling the public meeting. It would appear that the Indian parents refused to attend the public meeting and that, in view of their obstinate attitude, the teacher and the Indian agent interviewed...
interviewed them at their homes. They did not succeed, however, in persuading the parents that the children should return to school, nor have they returned at this date.

The Department of Education of Prince Edward Island was asked to make a special inspection of the Lennox Island School, particularly the work of the teacher during the last year, and report to the Department. This special inspection was made on October 24, by Merritt C. Colman, B.A. He reports that there were only three pupils (the children of the teacher) present at the time of inspection. The Inspector states:

"The school was very clean and tidy and Mr. Sark seems to be very interested in his work. I think that some pressure should be brought to bear on the parents of the children who are not attending school".

I should state that the Inspectors' reports on the work of this teacher have been uniformly good over a period of years. He has been employed for a period of 94 years as teacher at the Lennox Island School and is a returned soldier.

In addition to the correspondence already referred to, the Minister received a letter dated September 23, 1935, from the Honourable A. E. Arsenault, Judge of the Supreme Court of Prince Edward Island. In this letter the Judge states that a great deal of dissatisfaction exists amongst the parents of the children enrolled at the Lennox Island School and that the matter should be investigated by an official sent down from Ottawa or an official from New Brunswick or Nova Scotia.

Mr. A. E. MacLean, M.P., in a letter to the Department dated October 14, states:

"In view of all the circumstances, I think it would be just as well to leave the teacher at Lennox Island for the remainder of this year".

Reverend B. J. Macdonald, Parish Priest, in a letter dated August 23, states:

"I wish to testify that the teacher here, Mr. J. J. Sark, is most capable, that he is an influence for good among the Indian children and that he is a credit to the Indians of Prince Edward Island. I believe that those who signed the petition for his removal were not acting in the best interests of the tribe so I trust that your Department will carry out its usual thorough investigation before action is taken".

Chief Sark and his uncle, Isaac Peters, visited the Department two weeks ago and while here asked for the removal of the teacher. They stated definitely at that time that -
time that it was not the intention of the parents to permit their children to return to school until the teacher was removed and a new one engaged.

I am personally of the opinion that the teacher should not be dismissed at this time. The charges against him on the whole appear to be trivial and are the outcome of jealousy and deep-seated prejudices. He might, however, in the interests of himself and in the interests of the pupils, be allowed to go at the end of the academic year. In the meantime, however, the children are receiving no instruction and, being idle, are more apt to become wayward and unruly. I hesitate, therefore, to assume responsibility for the retention of the teacher, nor do I consider it wise, without an investigation, to recommend that the parents be prosecuted. If the Indians, however, are permitted to dictate to the Department in this case, it is difficult to say where such insubordination may end.

In view of these facts, it is just possible that you may desire to discuss this matter with the Minister or with the Deputy. It is scarcely necessary to add that a decision should be reached at an early date.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Memorandum:

DR. McSILL:

A petition has been received by the Department from a number of Indian residents of Prince Edward Island, asking that the children enrolled at the Lennox Island Indian Day School be transferred to the Shubenacadie Residential School, or, if such action were impossible at this time, that a new teacher be appointed to take charge of the Lennox Island School. This petition was received at the Department on July 21, 1938.

A letter dated July 22, 1938, was sent forward by this Branch to Mr. N. A. McDougall, Indian Agent, Summerside, P.E.I., asking him to make an investigation of the alleged grievances and to report to the Department.

Mr. McDougall, in his report dated August 9, states:

"I may say that I have had quite a number of complaints at different times regarding the way Mr. Sark, the teacher, punished the pupils. He is supposed to have made a practice of throwing up to the children of the school all wrongs their parents are doing or have done on the reserve - which is very childish. I have discussed this matter with Mr. Sark. He states that such reports are absolutely false. These are about the only complaints I have received and I feel that a letter from the Department to Mr. Sark, asking him to be a little more considerate with his pupils, would be all that is required. In conclusion I may state that any time I visited the Lennox Island School I found everything in order and the school well kept."

On August 15, 1938, a letter was sent to the teacher, in which the suggestion was made that he might be well advised to discuss the situation with the parents at a public meeting called for that purpose. The teacher did not reply to our communication of August 15, with the result that a second letter, dated September 30, was sent to him. A copy of this letter is attached. The teacher, in a lengthy communication dated October 5, explained that the delay in calling the meeting was due to a misunderstanding that had developed - the teacher being of the opinion that the Agent, and not himself, should take the initiative in calling the public meeting. It would appear that the Indian parents refused to attend the public meeting and that, in view of their obstinate attitude, the teacher and the Indian agent interviewed...
interviewed them at their homes. They did not succeed, however, in persuading the parents that the children should return to school, nor have they returned at this date.

The Department of Education of Prince Edward Island was asked to make a special inspection of the Lennox Island School, particularly the work of the teacher during the last year, and report to the Department. This special inspection was made on October 24 by Merritt E. Callaghan, B.A. He reports that there were only three pupils (the children of the teacher) present at the time of inspection. The Inspector states:

"The school was very clean and tidy and Mr. Sark seems to be very interested in his work. I think that some pressure should be brought to bear on the parents of the children who are not attending school."

I should state that the Inspectors' reports on the work of this teacher have been uniformly good over a period of years. He has been employed for a period of 24 years as teacher at the Lennox Island School and is a returned soldier.

In addition to the correspondence already referred to, the Minister received a letter dated September 23, 1938, from the Honourable A. E. Arsenault, Judge of the Supreme Court of Prince Edward Island. In this letter the Judge states that a great deal of dissatisfaction exists amongst the parents of the children enrolled at the Lennox Island School and that the matter should be investigated by an official sent down from Ottawa or an official from New Brunswick or Nova Scotia.

Mr. A. E. MacLean, M.P., in a letter to the Department dated October 14, states:

"In view of all the circumstances, I think it would be just as well to leave the teacher at Lennox Island for the remainder of this year."

Reverend B. J. Macdonald, Parish Priest, in a letter dated August 25, states:

"I wish to testify that the teacher here, Mr. J. J. Sark, is most capable, that he is an influence for good among the Indian children and that he is a credit to the Indians of Prince Edward Island. I believe that those who signed the petition for his removal were not acting in the best interests of the tribe, so I trust that your Department will carry out its usual thorough investigation before action is taken."

Chief Sark and his uncle, Isaac Peters, visited the Department two weeks ago and while here asked for the removal of the teacher. They stated definitely at that time that -
time that it was not the intention of the parents to permit their children to return to school until the teacher was removed and a new one engaged.

I am personally of the opinion that the teacher should not be dismissed at this time. The charges against him are, I think, appear to be trivial and are the outcome of jealousy and deep-seated prejudices. He might, however, in the interests of himself and in the interests of the pupils, be allowed to go at the end of the academic year. In the meantime, however, the children are receiving no instruction and, being idle, are more apt to become wayward and unruly. I hesitate, therefore, to assume responsibility for the retention of the teacher, nor do I consider it wise, without an investigation, to recommend that the parents be prosecuted. If the Indians, however, are permitted to dictate to the Department in this case, it is difficult to say where such insubordination may end.

In view of these facts, it is just possible that you may desire to discuss this matter with the Minister or with the Deputy. It is scarcely necessary to add that a decision should be reached at an early date.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
MEMORANDUM:

Deputy Minister,

I enclose correspondence with reference to difficulties at the Lennox Island School. It will be noted from Mr. Roey's report that the record of the teacher appears to be good throughout. He has been there a long time and the complaints appear to be made through a sense of spite and jealousy and appear to emanate from causes entirely unconnected with his teaching.

Under the circumstances I think it would be very unwise for the Branch to make the concessions asked for. This would amount to practically yielding to threat of force and withdrawal as it were under fire. Later a change may be advisable, but for the present I would recommend that the teacher be retained in his position.

Director of Indian Affairs.

Enclosure.

Dear Sir:

Specific instructions have been received from the office of the Minister with respect to the operation of the Lennox Island Indian Day School. The officials of this Branch have been instructed to take whatever action may be necessary to have the school open and in operation and the students now enrolled in attendance immediately following the Christmas holidays.

The conditions at this school have been carefully and sympathetically reviewed by the Department on a number of occasions since the re-opening of the school on September first. In view of your years of service at this school, the Department has no desire whatever to deal harshly with you in the matter. You can readily appreciate, however, that it is impossible for the Government to permit this school to continue in operation with three or four pupils in attendance. If this condition were permitted to continue, the Government would be subject to very severe criticism when the facts of the case became generally known. I am anxious to know if it is at all possible for you to persuade the Indian parents to have their children return to school immediately following Christmas. If this is impossible, you should accept this letter as a notice to send in your resignation to the Department at once. Such action on your part will enable us to secure a teacher to take charge of the school early in January.

I am sending a copy of this letter to the Indian Agent and asking him to discuss the matter with you.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

In pursuance of my telegram of Dec 21st.

I have been very busy endeavoring to get the children of the defaulting family back to school, and have succeeded in my efforts to the extent of getting the children of John Labobe to attend and the children of Anthony Labobe are young and delicate and no doubt the remaining two children will attend during the summer months. You will understand two children of this family are now in the Sanitorium. There only remains the family of Chief Sark to deal with. Now Chief Sark has been absent in procuring ash in New Brunswick, and has only recently returned, and just at the present time they are practically isolated on the Lennox Island Reserve due to bad roads, and weather conditions in general. I would point out that the crossing from Port Hill is impossible at the present time, the ice is not solid enough to permit travel on foot, and yet the ferry is unable to operate. However as soon as crossing from Port Hill permits I will make a special visit to interview Chief Sark, and I feel practically between the teacher and myself we can induce him to send his children. There are two children of Mrs. Sylvain Sark, a widow now married to Patk Bernard who moves to Alberton every winter, and these children will be deprived of attending during the winter months.

I might state there are only two children of Chief Sark's of school age and we are successful there will be a total of eight pupils attending, and of course the two of Anthony Labobe who are delicate would make ten pupils.
I would also point out there are a number of the Lennox Island pupils attending Shubenacadie School.

However, after a consultation with Chief Sark, I will advise you further.

The delay in answering your letter and telegram was due to the fact that I was and still am unable to get in touch with the Chief, on account of weather conditions.

Mr. Hey,

Re: Teachers - Lennox Island Day School.

During my last visit to Prince Edward Island I had an interview with His Excellency James Boyle, D.D., Charlottetown, with reference to the appointment of a priest.

Bishop Boyle assured me he would co-operate in every way possible and endeavour to appoint a priest, who would be fully qualified to teach, as well as to organize boy scouts, girl guides, and generally supervise social and athletic entertainment.

I also interviewed Sister Mary Theresa, Superior General of the Order of St. Martha. The Superior was very doubtful if she would be able to provide two fully qualified teaching sisters. However, after the whole project was explained to her, she gave me to understand that she would do all in her power to meet our requirements.

There is every reason to believe that the school will be constructed and ready for classes to begin in September; approximate enrollment will be between fifty-five and sixty-five. This number would not justify engaging the services of two teachers and a principal and, as it is imperative to have a parish priest available, so that the sisters could attend Mass in the morning daily, I would recommend that the parish priest be engaged as a teacher to instruct one of the classes. His Excellency James Boyle readily approved of the suggestion. The teacher would receive a teaching salary, which would make it possible for him to carry on his work, and not have to worry about his monthly expenses. The Sunday collection at the different Masses would not be sufficient to cover his living costs.

If this suggestion is approved then the present parish house will have to be repaired and remodelled. This could be done during the summer at very little cost when the school and the Agent's house is being constructed as, undoubtedly, we will have surplus building material available. I would, therefore, strongly recommend that the teaching staff consist of one teaching sister and priest.

Health and Welfare Service have agreed to pay the salary of a nursing sister and the Superior General has promised that she will try to supply a qualified nurse. Living quarters will be provided in the teachers' residence for a nursing sister. It is hope that by paying full salaries to two sisters, one a teacher and one a nurse, that the Superior General will find it possible to provide the services of a sister housekeeper without cost to the Department.

If my recommendation is approved then I would suggest that a letter be sent to Bishop Boyle advising him of our needs and the salaries that would be paid.

My dear Mr. Hoey:

I have your letter of the 28th ult., which I have now submitted to His Excellency the Bishop.

Your letter leaves no alternative to the Bishop and myself, and we reluctantly have to agree to your proposition, subject to what follows. I have tried to impress your Department, evidently without success, that the success of the scheme on Lennox Island is dependent on three things working together: 1. The presence of the Indian Agent; 2. The presence of a resident parish priest; 3. The establishment of the Order of the Martha's there; and that these three factors working in unison would succeed in establishing an industrious and contented community. To this end, the parish priest is a most necessary element, for without his presence there we could not have the sisters. Without his presence, and without deprecating in any way the Agent (an excellent young man), I doubt that the Agent could keep order in the community or that he could organize it on the social side. And again the success of the scheme depends on the Indians being not only occupied but socially entertained.

No community of this kind can succeed if its morals are not protected and carefully guarded, and this is one of the responsibilities of the parish priest. On the social side, the community must have sources of entertainment, and for the purpose it is the intention to install a moving picture machine in the Hall together with a radio and a gramophone recorder.

It will also be necessary to organize entertainments such as concerts, plays and parties and dances, all of which will
have to be under the care and direction of the parish priest assisted by the sisters.

Other necessary and useful activities will be the organization of swimming classes for the boys and girls, baseball, football and hockey and, to keep up the interest, Indian teams would compete with similar teams of white boys which are now organized in the different parts of the County (Prince).

I also wish to stress the importance of such organizations as the Red Cross, both Senior and Junior, Boy Scouts and Girl Guides. I submit, and without hesitation, that the Agent with his many other occupations will be able to give very little time to these activities, and that the burden of organizing and overseeing these activities will fall to the parish priest.

I ask then, in all sincerity, how the parish priest, after attending to the moral and spiritual needs of the community and spending a large part of the day in teaching, can be expected to successfully carry on these other activities.

Apart from all these, there are as well, the classes in handicraft and manual training, and as to who will organize and direct these classes I have no knowledge, but no doubt, again, the burden would fall on the parish priest. The sisters are willing to teach the handicraft classes in all its branches, but as to the manual training for boys, I have no information, and again these will require the direction and oversight of the parish priest.

You say in your letter that in this alternative, instead of teaching, the Lady Wood Fund could be used to meet the parish priest's living expenses. In this respect may I point out that the interest on this Fund, which on an average will not exceed $500. or $600. per year, is an amount altogether inadequate for the living expenses of the parish priest, besides the fact that this interest can be profitably used to help out financial needs in connection with the activities I have above mentioned.
I am satisfied that the Department and its officers have the success of the undertaking at heart, as I myself have, and that success is vitally dependent on the program outlined above, and the failure to carry it out will greatly prejudice the undertaking. As you are well aware, I have given nine years' study and consideration to this project; I have corresponded with and sought the advice of those best qualified to give it, and what I have outlined is the result of much study and advice obtained, and I have been led to believe that the result of my studies and investigation have been of some value and assistance to the Department, and I feel that the Department will co-operate to the fullest extent in having the suggestions, which from time to time I have been able to propose, carried out.

Finally, in view of all I have said and written, it is still considered that there are no other means to take care of the parish priest's living than by having him spend the best part of his time in teaching, we can only submit, feeling at the same time that it is the wrong course to take.

I can only add that the sisters have now made arrangements to have four of their best qualified sisters go to Lennox Island next September, but on the distinct understanding that at least three of them will be on salary, otherwise they could not financially carry on their work.

I do not apologize for the length of this communication, for the importance of what I have said fully justifies it.

Lastly, please bear in mind that we are asking refined gentlewomen as well as a highly educated cleric to cut themselves off from the society of their fellows to live on an Island separated from the mainland with people with whom, in a purely spirit of charity, they will spend their lives to educate and try to make their sad lot a more contented and happier one.

I am, sir,

My dear Mr. Hoey:

I beg to acknowledge letter from your Department of April 7th in reply to His Excellency's letter to you.

I regret that my letter to you of March 9th has not been considered worthy of a reply.

What is being done in connection with the repair of the parochial residence is only what would be expected to supply living quarters for the male teacher of the school. I infer from your letter that it is not the intention of the Department to make provision for the teaching of Home Handicraft, Household Science, including sewing, knitting, darning &c. In other words, no part of the program which I have outlined in previous letters, and which I discussed with Dr. Camsell and Dr. McGill and myself, and which was favourably received, will be carried out. This is most unfortunate, and knocks the bottom out of a project that was considered essential to the success of the scheme for the rehabilitation of the Indians, and on the plea of economy.

The Department of Mines and Resources does not hesitate in spending a yearly sum of $100,000. and over in the upkeep of the National Park, a strip of some 100 yards in depth along the north shore of the Province, which is used in a large part in keeping up an 18 hole golf course for the benefit of a minimum of players, and the upkeep of the grounds at Dalvay. Yet the wards of the Department - the Indians - must be stinted on the grounds of economy.
The lay-out as I now understand will be the employment of one male and one female teacher for the school and one social service nurse; but no provisions are being made for the other essential activities, or is it contemplated that these activities will be carried out by the teachers and the nurse free of cost to the Department.

If the school is to be the only result of the energy I have expended in this scheme for the past nine years, then it has been a case of "laborat montem &c." I cannot here express my disappointment and, should I say, disillusion.

I am, Sir

Yours truly,

[Signature]
April 16, 1948.

My dear Justice Arsenault:

I regret that illness and absence from the office have prevented me from dealing with your letter of March 9th and also one of April 12th until now.

I have, however, read carefully the departmental letter to you dated April 7th. I find it difficult to understand why you have reached certain conclusions with respect to our educational program at Prince Edward Island following the receipt of this particular letter. The educational program that the department will provide for the group of Indians in whom you are interested will be based on the needs of the Indian population and will form part of an educational program organized throughout the whole of the Dominion. This program, coupled with the scale of salaries now paid to teachers and the provision now made for superannuation allowances to our teachers, has won favourable comment from educationists in practically all of the provinces. Provision is made in the elementary course for a certain amount of instruction in elementary domestic science in the case of girls and a certain amount of vocational instruction in the case of boys. In view of the fact, however, that it is our intention to encourage in the future a large number of Indian pupils to proceed to high school, our program must have the approval of the provincial educational authorities who, as you know, issue high school entrance certificates, high school leaving certificates and matriculation certificates.

I would not be perfectly frank with you if I did not state that I know of no group of Indians in
Canada who will be provided for in the same sense that the Indians of P.E.I. will be provided for when our program is completed. We have, as you know, on the Island at present a population of approximately 250 Indians. We shall have in charge of these Indians a full-time Indian Agent, a part-time doctor, a public health nurse, a school principal and, at least, one school teacher. The advisability of having a constable for the Island is now under review and consideration.

A glance at last year's welfare expenditures alone indicate that the expenditures in P.E.I. and the province of Nova Scotia far exceed other expenditures on Indian advancement in other sections of the Dominion. For example, if somewhat similar expenditures had been made in the province of Ontario, our disbursements in that province would have amounted to $3,000,000.00, whereas our actual expenditures amounted to $285,827.00. Should we compare expenditures in Nova Scotia and P.E.I. with expenditures on Indian advancement in the Northwest Territories, the discrepancy would be still more discriminatory. I cannot, when confronted with a request that additional expenditures in P.E.I. be made, forget the fact that there are in Canada at this moment 12,000,000 children of school age for whom no educational facilities whatever have been provided. You will, I trust, realize that conditions on our Indian reserves will require the exercise of a great deal of patience, insight and understanding. It is scarcely fair to ask the officials now in charge of Indian administration to accomplish overnight what should have been accomplished continuously during the years of the last century. However, your interest in this particular group and your desire to help them is very much appreciated.

Yours sincerely,

The Honourable A. E. Arsenault,
Charlottetown,
P. E. I.

Attached is a copy of a communication from Mr. Neary of the Educational Division of Indian Affairs Branch. It introduces the situation at Lennox Island where there are by census 266 micmacs presently receiving irregular visits from the local physicians only. Recently the Indian Affairs Branch have constructed a school and teachers' residence wherein they have made available to us at our expense, a dispensary and living quarters for a nurse.

The number of Indians would justify approximately one-quarter of a nurse's salary. On the other hand the nurse would presumably not perform any other functions either at the school or in the white community, which is some distance away, and if she is to be retained for the express purpose of looking after the Indians, it would seem that we must pay a full salary.

I am not prepared to suggest what salary we should pay until you have had time to consider the situation and recommend whether the position should be created through the Civil Service or the nurse reimbursed on voucher. And Convent Island Opened

Yesterday was a red letter day in the history of Lennox Island when at 2 p.m. Lieutenant-Governor Bernard officially opened the new combined school and convent building on the island which comprised not only all the Indians on the island but several hundred from various parts of the Province.

The Rt. Rev. A. E. Arsenault, retired Justice of the Supreme Court of the Province, who has for more than thirty years been a persistent advocate of better treatment for the Indians of Lennox Island, presided at the opening ceremonies.

In his opening remarks he paid a warm tribute to the Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, for having made available the money necessary to erect the splendid buildings which, he said, would be of great benefit socially, economically and spiritually to the Indian boys and girls now living on Lennox Island.

Hon. G. H. Barbour said he was pleased to represent the Premier of the Government at the ceremony. The Department of Indian Affairs had done an excellent job in selecting the school, rectory, power house, also covering the cost of the Indian agent, Mr. L. J. Daly, Mr. Daniel McDonald, Sydney, N.S., who had been engaged during the construction, had done fine work, Mr. Barbour said, and was deserving of congratulation.

Fine Institution

Dr. L. W. Shaw, director of education, said the new school at Lennox Island was one of the finest, if not the finest institution of its kind in the Province. It was not only a school in the ordinary sense of the word, but was a complete school since its two departments of primary training and secondary science entitled it to be ranked as such. So far as the teaching staff was concerned, Mr. Shaw said he had no doubt whatever that Father MacMillan and his personal knowledge of the teaching ability of the Indians, Dr. MacMillan said, were equal to or superior to any teacher in the Province.

Dr. T. V. Grant, M.P., said there had been nothing more favourable to the undertaking of the project which had recently been completed at Lennox Island.

His Honour congratulated the Indians on the progress they were making toward self-support and independence and told them that henceforth their boys and girls would be able to secure an educational foundation as would enable them to earn their living in any part of the Dominion.

Commends Facilities

His Excellency Bishop Boyle said he was very pleased present and to see for himself the splendid facilities which were being erected for the social and cultural advancement of the Indians of St. Anne's Parish. He had always spoken with some length at the celebration of Solemn Mass, Mass Hill, and said he could make his remarks by assuring the people of the parish that he was ready at all times to do what he could for their welfare, both spiritual and material.

Hon. G. H. Barbour said he was pleased to represent the Premier of the Government at the ceremony. The Department of Indian Affairs had done an excellent job in selecting the school, rectory, power house, also covering the cost of the Indian agent, Mr. L. J. Daly, Mr. Daniel McDonald, Sydney, N.S., who had been engaged during the construction, had done fine work, Mr. Barbour said, and was deserving of congratulation.

Opening Ceremonies

Yesterday's ceremonies opened at 10 a.m. with the celebration of Solemn Mass in St. Anne's Church, by the pastor the Rev. W. M. McNichol, Rev. J. D. Keir, the Rev Leonard McDonald, St. George's, Charlottetown, and the Rev. J. W. McCauley, Charlottetown.

In his sermon Bishop Boyle paid warm tribute to the great work done on Lennox Island by Mrs. John Park, widow of the late Chief John Sart. In speaking as a young girl to Lennox Island 30 years ago where her parents lived.

British Intruder

Here's Great Britain's bid for a new carrier-borne jet fighter. The Hawker Sea Hawk, seen here, has folding wings to facilitate storage on a flight deck. The Hawker, however, has special landing gear built into the fuselage.

Indian Federal Assistance

Mr. J. E. Morris said his department intended to give the Indians at Lennox Island every opportunity to become independent and self-supporting for a livelihood. Already the Department had placed a premium on improving the quality of the cattle raised on the island. At present there were eight milking cows on the island valued at $800.

The Department had also planted 100 apple trees on the island and would plant 100 cherry trees on the island as well as some 2500 strawberries. All these plants were being looked after by competent persons and the number of trees, strawberries, plants etc., would be increased considerably as the Indians showed themselves capable of profiting by them.

The community store, Mr. Morris said, would supply the communities usually found in a general store, but the Indians would be given the chance to turn back to them in the form of a permanent residence for the Indian agent, Mr. L. J. Daly, who filled the long-felt need now Mr. Daly, an unusually competent and sincere officer...
Splendid School Is Officially Opened On Lennox Island

Modern Building Will Provide Facilities for Teaching Domestic Science and Manual Training as Well as Two Splendidly Equipped Rooms for Academic Instruction

"We are very proud of the developments here," Chief Frank Jadin said of the recent improvements in the accommodations at Lennox Island. The occasion was the opening of the new school, described by Dr. L. W. Shaw, Deputy Minister of Education, as one of the finest in the province. And the remark was no exaggeration, Chief Jadis had reason to be proud.

The opening ceremonies held yesterday afternoon were held in front of the new building which also houses the Sisters of St. Joseph who will teach the primary department of the school, the training in practical nursing care and first aid facilities.

The new school was officially opened by His Honor Lieutenant-Governor J. A. Bernard at a ceremony presided over by Hon. A. E. Arensoull, retired Supreme Court Judge. Other speakers were His Excellency Bishop James Boyle, Hon. G. H. Barbour who represented the Premier, Dr. L. W. Shaw who spoke for the Department of Education, Dr. J. V. Grant, M.P., Rev. MacMillan, Rev. E. W. McInnis, Rev. E. W. McInnis, Parish Priest and Principal of the new school.

Rooms beautifully finished and equipped are on the ground floor. In the basement are two other rooms, one for teaching manual training and the other for teaching domestic science. In the basement are also lavatories for the teachers and washrooms and lavatories for boys and girls.

My dear Dr. Keenleyside:

You are no doubt aware that the formal opening of the Indian School at Lennox Island came off with great success on Monday the 13th inst. The ceremony was performed by the Lieutenant-Governor, and His Excellency Bishop Bayle was also present. The Premier, who was unavoidably absent, was represented by his Minister of Roads and Public Works Mr. Barbeau.

Under separate cover, I enclose you reports from "The Guardian" and "Patriot" newspapers. I am sure that you will be interested in reading these, and I would ask that you kindly pass them on to the Director of Indian Affairs.

May I say that it is rather important that the domestic science department and the manual training department should be organized at as early a date as possible. I trust that provisions will also be made to supply the Indians with ample material with which to work during the winter. Otherwise they would have to be supplied with means of relief by the Department. With plenty of such material, the Indians could make sufficient during the winter months to pay their way.

There are also the matters on which I beg leave to make representations later on.

I am, sir,

Yours faithfully,

A. E. ARSENAULT.

Sir,

As requested by a letter from the Department dated 14th November No. 116737, I bring before it the necessity of removing the school house to a more central place. There will be a three weeks' vacation in October; and if the school house is to be removed, it would be the proper time to do the work. The floor has to be torn off; it is pretty well wore off, and new sashes and frames has to be put in, and it must be shingled all over except roof, paper must also be put under shingles to make it warm. A new door and lock will be required.

I cannot make an estimate, but it must cost over $125.00. It is an old building and it must be repaired though it was not removed. I think there would be a larger attendance in the winter if the school house was about three quarters of a mile nearer the cover, as the greater number of the scholars live in that settlement.

Perhaps it will not cost more to pull it down to pieces and rebuild it on the spot than to haul it, if remove by hauling, the plaster will fall off, and will require plastering as if torn to pieces to remove it.

I am, Sir,
your obedient servant,

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo No. 11437-5, referring to the building a new school house on Lennox Island. In reply I may say that I have lately seen a country school house built last year and was informed by two rate-payers Messrs. Bentham and Ellis, that the building cost $600.00 being 32 ft long 22 ft wide and 18 ft high, but as the one proposed to build on Lennox Island need not be so large, would cost considerably less. I think a building such as would be required viz. 20 ft long 20 ft wide and 18 ft high should be built for $500.00 and be well finished and painted and underpinned with stones for that amount.

As to using the materials in the old building, only the boards could be used for the posts and rafters are too short and could not be used, and to get at the boards and pull out nails from them would cost nearly as much as to buy new boards. The old building would be very useful to the band for a hall for meetings. They have as the Deport. is aware organized a Temperance Society some years ago, and they hold their meetings in the school house, and it is the proper place for such meetings and the society has done a great deal of good among the Indians.

So if the Department was willing the old school house would be kept for that purpose, I enclose a sketch of building required, I cannot make a plan.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

OTTAWA, June 21st, 1921.

Rev. Sir,

The Public School Inspector, Mr. Auld, in a report to the Department on his recent inspection of the Lennox Island Indian Day School, states that the teacher was dissatisfied that the school was not being scrubbed more frequently.

After the summer holidays you should enquire into this complaint, and arrange to have the school room scrubbed at frequent intervals.

The inspector also draws attention to the need of painting the school building on the outside. The Department has no funds specially provided for the purpose, but will be pleased to receive an estimate of the cost of having the school building painted on the outside with two coats of paint.

When this information is received, the question of having the work done will be given consideration.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. J. A. McDonald,
Indian Superintendent,
Grand River, Lot 14,
P.E.I.
Sir,

I visited the school and also the Janitor and instructed him to have the building scrubbed out at least every two months as part of his duties for which he receives $50.00 annually.

With the suggestion of the inspector Mr Auld, he probably wished to recommend some improvement for the betterment of the school surroundings. He was pleased with everything he saw there and gave a good report of the standing of the school and thru the press placed it on an equality with the white schools of the surrounding districts and in some things above the average.

I would recommend that the painting of the building be dispensed with at least for this year. Later on, paint and oil will probably be cheaper. Besides the building was never painted but whitewashed and I do not think it would be advisable to put paint over the whitewash unless the whitewash were all scraped off, which would be expensive. The whitewash under the paint would be apt to scale off and take the paint with it.

I think if it were whitewashed as it was before it would be sufficient. The material and work of whitewashing the building should not exceed ten Dollars.

Reverend Sir:

The teacher of the Lennox Island Indian Day School, in his annual report for the fiscal year ended March 31st, last, states that the roof of the building leaks badly, also that a coal shed is needed to store the winter's supply of fuel.

I have to request that you will, upon the occasion of your next visit to Lennox Island, enquire into the condition of the roof and, if only minor repairs are required, you may arrange to have them carried out. If, however, it will be necessary to re-shingle the roof, you should state approximately the cost of the material needed and the labour involved.

Please state whether you would advise having a coal shed erected. If needed, a small, inexpensive building with a lean-to roof, rough board walls and a strong door equipped with lock and key would answer the purpose. You should state approximately the cost of this type of shed and inform us whether it could be erected by Indian labour if the material was supplied.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. J. A. McDonald,
Indian Superintendent,
Grand River, Lot 14,
P. R. I.
Sir,

At the time the letter came there was too much snow to allow of examining the building properly.

Since then I have examined it and find that it will be better to have the roof shingled completely. The building is 25 ft x 20 ft and the roof will require about 7 thousand of shingles @ $5.00 per M. and about 35 pounds of galvanized nails. Staging will also be needed and there will be freight on the shingles and the work of taking off the old shingles and shingling with the new ones will take in all about $75.00 perhaps more perhaps a little less. It is claimed that new cedar shingles will last longer if they are not painted the first year and then painted when they have dried up. The cost of painting the roof would take about $20.00 or $25.00.

With regard to the putting up of a building for coal I consulted the teacher and advised that a part of the cloak room at the entrance to the building would be sufficient for the purpose. Five tons were stored there last winter and there was ample room in the entry on the other side of the door for the children's clothes. The floor sagged a little but not much and could be easily propped up. I showed the teacher how it would be a great advantage to have the coal at hand instead of going outside to another building for it in winter. However it is deemed advisable to have a shed built for coal one could be built for about $25.00. It would need to have a lock and a shingled roof to keep the coal dry.

I don't know how much it would cost to have the interior made white but it would not cost much. I could have this work done during the summer if instructed by the Department.

June 27th, 1936

Dear Sir,

It has been brought to my attention that the school on the Kenora Island Reserve is very badly in need of repair. This is a matter of great importance and I made a special trip to the Reserve to view the situation.

I find the site in poor condition, and completely also the flag poles, which caused the flags to drop down a foot or more. I may say that I believe the condition to be brought about largely by a lack of work which is just inside the entrance door. This is not only detrimental to the floor of the school, but there is always a certain amount of coal dust accumulates on the walls, doors, etc., which makes it difficult to keep clean and sanitary.

The school is very badly in need of painting on the interior, and badly heat-painted for twenty-seven years.

I would recommend that a covered porch be erected apart from the school. I have figured on the construction of the shed 66'8", the dimensions of which will be 10' x 14'1".

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6059, file 270-5, part 2)
The school can be put in proper repair and painted for $685 which seems very reasonable.

Regarding the school grounds, there is a large portion of waste growing up with bushes, some of which are quite high. The two toilets are situated on the lowest part of the grounds and it is almost impossible for children to get them in nice weather. These toilets can be removed about fifty feet and would be on high ground, and would look much better in appearance. I figure that this work could be done for about fifteen dollars, ready to be performed by the residents of the Reserve.

The cost of shoveling and repairing school, and fixing up of the grounds, would amount in all to $1885 and I would recommend that these works be done during the holiday season which is most out.

Kindly let me hear from you at your earliest convenience.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Sir:

I was today interviewed by the Chief Jacob Sark regarding a pump for the Indian Day School on the Lennox Island Reserve.

It has been the custom for the school children to carry water from the Chief's house, which is a distance of about ten chains, which you can see, makes it rather inconvenient for the children during the winter months. It also causes inconvenience to the Chief, as the children generally spill water on the floor. I might say that the Chief is not being remunerated for supplying the water, as is the custom among the public schools elsewhere on the Island where there is no pump. The Chief informs me, that just recently, his pump has been broken and it will cost him some money to have it repaired.

Would you kindly let me know if the Dept. is prepared to authorize an amount of money for the sinking of a pump for this School.

Dear Sir:

I have a matter to bring to your attention, viz., the stove and toilets used in the Indian Day School of the Lennox Island Reserve.

The stove is burned, not only the linings, but right through the outer part, in fact burned beyond repair. I have priced the stoves in the local stores and find that the most suitable heater would be a No. 12 glebe Heater, which will cost $21.50.

Re the toilets, the sashes and sills are rotted out completely, and the roof of one toilet needs shingling. I would estimate the repairing of the two toilets at approximately $15.00.

Kindly advise me what the Dept. is prepared to do in these matters.

Dear Sir:

I wish to bring to your attention the matter of some cleaning up and repairs which I wish to have done to the Lennox Island School. You will note that this school was painted two years ago, but is again in need of being washed and varnished, that is the ceiling, walls, windows, etc.

You will also understand that the Dept. is making a special drive to check tuberculosis and this start will be made by examining all school children just as soon as school closes for vacation. I therefore think it necessary to have this work done.

There will be some little repairs to desks, and a couple of hinges for doors, and about a half dozen panes of glass for windows.

I feel that this work can be done including the price of material for approximately twenty five dollars.

Awaiting your reply, I remain

Your obedient servant,

Yours truly,

H.A. Hoey,
Director,
Indian Affairs Branch
OTTAWA.

I would like to know if any arrangements have been made to build the new school and agency buildings on Lennox Island this coming summer; we do want a school in the worst way, and I am hoping plans are on the way to carry this project out.

J. S. Daly
Indian Agent
Ottawa, April 29, 1946.

Mr. J. E. Daly, Indian Agent,
Charlottetown, Prince Edward Island.

I have your letter of the 15th instant, with reference to the erection of a new school at Lennox Island this year.

Owing to the policy of encouraging the erection of private homes, our public building program has been curtailed and, as a result, it was found impossible to make provision in the 1946-47 appropriation for the erection of a new school at Lennox Island.

Please let me know the number of children of school age who, you anticipate, will require educational facilities for the academic year 1946-47, which begins on September 1, next. How many children can be accommodated in the present school? Is there any building that could be rented, temporarily, and used as a school for a year or so, until we can secure the necessary funds for the erection of a new school. Please let me hear from you in regard to the above.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
May 2nd, 1946.

J. E. Daly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Charlottetown, P.E.I.

With reference to that portion of your letter of April 15th which refers to the construction of buildings, Mr. Phelan has written to you in regard to the school.

With reference to the construction of the Indian Agency residence this year, I would say that funds have been provided and we hope that a contract will be awarded. However, this matter will be in the hands of the Surveys and Engineering Branch, and I am unable to tell you at the present time how soon the work will commence.

Director.

OTTAWA.

I have your letter of the 29th instant, with reference to a new school for Lennox Island, and it is noted that it has been found impossible to make provision in the 1946-47 appropriation for same.

In regard to the number of children who will require educational facilities during the coming school year, I anticipate that there shall be about 35 or possibly 40 if we can get them all moved back to the Reserve, and as you already know there is 18 in the Residential School at Shubenacadie, in all there should be about 55 or 58 going to the school on the Reserve, at the present time the school will accommodate 24.

There is not any building that we could use temporarily, except we can build something in the shape of a school, and it would seem to me that would not be very satisfactory except we could employ two teachers, and I am doubtful even if that arrangement would be suitable on the Reserve.

J. E. Daly  
Indian Agent.

Re: The construction of 2-roomed school
with teacher's residence, Indian Agent's
residence, septic tank and outdoor toilets for
school — Lennox Island Reserve, P.E.I.

On May 26th we forwarded to Indian Agent Daly a copy of
the plan of the house for the Indian Agent, together with a copy
of the specifications and the plans of the school building,
together with the specifications, were sent to Indian Agent Daly
at a later date.

Indian Agent Daly was asked to show the plans and
specifications to any contractors who might be interested and to
try to secure a lump sum price. Mr. Daly advised in June that
the firm of Schurman and Co. of Charlottetown were interested in
tendering. Nothing further was heard from Mr. Daly until late
in August when he wired for the plans of the septic tank and the
size of the cut houses required for the school. The following
telegram was sent to Mr. Morris in connection with the questions
raised by Mr. Schurman:

"Schurman asked for and was furnished with plan
showing detail of two chamber septic tank and instructed
not to figure on smaller tank in view of possible expansion
at this agency. Today he wired for plan of disposal bed and
distance septic tank from residence, or length and size
inlet and total length and size disposal drains. Schurman
should visit the site and someone should indicate the site
to him. The position of the septic tank in relation to
house and location of disposal bed in relation to septic
tank will have to be determined by the site allowing for
proper amount of fall to each disposal bed. Advise Schurman
to quote on all the work. Plans of outside toilets for
school also furnished to him."
In a letter dated September 10th, Mr. Morris informed us that Mr. Schurman was quoting on the understanding that construction would commence in the spring, both buildings to be completed in time for the opening of the school. I believe it is the intention of Mr. Schurman, if his price is accepted, to prepare at the mill in Summerside the forms, window frames, sash, doors, door frames, etc., and have these ready to ship in the spring.

I do not believe we would be justified or that regulations would permit us to accept the tender for the construction of a building when building operations will not start until next year. I would, however, like to have your opinion on Mr. Schurman's price before advising him that his tender cannot be accepted but that he will be given another opportunity to tender on or about April 1st.

In view of the fact that the items for the construction of these two buildings have been cleared through the Department of Reconstruction, there will not be, in my opinion, any difficulty in getting the items re-voted in our 1948-49 Estimates and we intend to include these buildings in the Estimates. There is now plenty of time to advertise for tenders and I would like to have your assurance that you will be prepared to call for tenders on April 1st. Additional copies of the plans and specifications which the contractors will need to tender on can be prepared together with the advertisement and everything assembled so that the ad can appear in the newspapers the first week in April. I believe that no one from your Branch has visited the site of this building and that the site has been chosen by our Acting Inspector. I would suggest that the site be visited this fall and that any other information that is needed be secured this fall so that there will be no possibility of delays in the spring.

These buildings should be provided with light and water and if this has not been taken care of in the plans and specifications I would suggest that a short specification and whatever else is necessary to provide electricity be prepared so that the contractors
can figure on this phase of the work as well as on the buildings.

In the opinion of Mr. Morris who has been at Laxen Island for the last few days, a well should be drilled this fall. Mr. Morris states that there is no difficulty in obtaining water at any location on Laxen Island. Please let me know whether we should proceed with the drilling of the well or whether you would advise us to wait until a number of your staff has visited the site and approved of the locations chosen. The well should, no doubt, be drilled close to the buildings and we have in mind that a number of your staff might change the location which has been chosen. I am putting an urgent tag on this memorandum and would very much appreciate a reply in a few days. There may be some phases of this matter that I have overlooked. If so, I would appreciate them being drawn to my attention.

Director.

DEPARTMENTAL EXPLANATION

In our 1947-48 Estimates, we asked for the sum of $18,000.00 for the construction of a two-room school and residence at Lennox Island. On December 1, 1947, we made application for the transfer of $10,000.00 of this sum to be made to the East Coast Agency in British Columbia for the completion of a classroom block at the Alberni Residential School.

At that time we had been unable to make any satisfactory arrangements with a contractor for the construction of the Lennox Island school. However, we have now been able to purchase from Mr. Amos Cooperstone, buildings at the Mount Pleasant Street, N.W., and have arranged for a foreman to supervise the erection of these buildings which we will move across the ice to Lennox Island. Next spring, we can have our foreman supervise the construction of this school from this used lumber, employing Indian labour. Memorandum:

The Director,

Re: Electric Power, Lennox Island Agency Headquarters.

To supply electricity for the Agency Buildings, namely, school, teacher's residence, Agent's residence, principal's residence, and pump house, it will be necessary to install a Diesel electric power manufacturing unit with a 12 to 15 k. rating, 110-220 volts, 60 cycle, single phase.

During my last visit to P.H.I., I interviewed the Engineers-in-Charge of the Summerside Electrical Power Plant and they advised me that because of the great number of requests for electrical power and as their power supply is limited, they could not consider an application from this office to supply electrical power for our use at Lennox Island. Note: the closest small town is Tyne Valley four miles distance; three miles over land and one mile over water. The Tyne Valley Municipality have been requesting a supply of electric power for a number of years but, to date, they have not been successful in obtaining it. Under the circumstances, I would recommend that we establish our own electric power unit on the Island.

I have discussed the type of power unit that might be suitable for our needs with Engineer R. H. Ross and Mr. Vincent Cooner, of the Lands and Development Services. Mr. Ross surveyed the building sites at Lennox Island in the Fall of 1947 and is fully informed of our needs. I would, therefore, strongly recommend that a request be sent to the Engineering and Construction Division asking them to investigate and advise the type of Diesel electric power unit required.

I might point out that when we dismantled one of the pumping stations purchased at the Mount Pleasant Airport, we salvaged an International Gas Engine, Model PA-100, which is in perfect working condition. This engine is worth approximately $2,500.
and if an International Diesel electrical manufacturing power unit is selected and available, it is just possible that the gas engine PA-100 could be traded in on the purchase of the Diesel engine to good advantage.

J. E. Morris.

P.S. Note: There is a R.C. Church and an Indian owned Community Hall in the vicinity of the Agency Headquarters. It is suggested that the power unit be large enough to provide electricity to these buildings also.
April 1st, 1946.

The Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch.

Attention of Mr. C. Buck - Architect.

Electricity will have to be supplied to the agency buildings and school buildings on the Leamux Island Indian Reserve, P. R. I., namely agent's residence, office and store, pumping stations in which will be located the pump and lighting plant, the school, teachers' residence, principal's residence. It is desired also to supply power to the Church and the Indian owned Community Hall.

It has been ascertained that electrical energy cannot be secured from the Summerland Electric Power Company, and we will have to provide our own source of power.

The type of power unit suitable for our needs have been discussed by Mr. Morris with Engineer Ross and Mr. Kosmar of your service and Mr. Ross is, I understand, fully informed of our needs.

As you know we have dismantled buildings at the Mount Pleasant airport, and we salvaged an International Gas Engine, Model PA-100, which is reported to be in perfect working condition and worth about $2,500.00. It has been suggested that if an International Diesel Electric Lighting Plant is selected there is a possibility that the engine mentioned above could be traded in on the purchase.

In specifying the light and power plant required to furnish light and power to the buildings mentioned I would ask that consideration be given to specifying the International Diesel so that a trade-in could be arranged.

At the earliest possible date will you kindly let me have a specification for a suitable plant.

Director.

On 6-4-48 a complaint was received at this detachment office to the effect that several windows were broken at the public school at Lennox Island Indian Reserve, P.E.I. This complaint was lodged by Chief Jacob Sark of Lennox Island Indian Reserve, P.E.I.

2. On 7-4-48 writer in company with 2/Cst. Thorson patrolled to Lennox Island Indian Reserve, P.E.I. to investigate this complaint. Patrol learned that six small windows had been broken, but had already been replaced when the patrol arrived at Lennox Island. Investigation disclosed that these windows had been broken by two small juvenile boys, namely Gerald Tuplin aged five years and John Peter Bernard aged six years. Patrol spoke to the parents of both boys and they assured writer that another incident like this would not happen again. Patrol interviewed Chief Jacob Sark and advised him of the investigation carried out. Sark advised patrol that he did not want any further action taken due to the age of the boys.

3. In view of the above this file is being considered closed at this detachment.

Ottawa, August 31, 1948.

Re: Generating Equipment, Lennox Island, Prince Edward Island.

We are in receipt of tenders for generating equipment for the above, submitted to the Indian Affairs Branch by the Departmental Purchasing Agent and forwarded to this Division by hand for our analysis.

The following is a summary of the tenders received:

(a) Northern Electric Company Limited, Ottawa - $5,327.00 each - 60 days f.o.b. Minneapolis, Minn.

(b) Canadian Fairbanks Morse Company Limited, Ottawa - $4,886.00 each - two to four weeks f.o.b. Port Hill, P.E.I.

(c) General Supply Co. of Canada Limited, Ottawa - $4,068.00 each - twelve to sixteen weeks f.o.b. Ottawa.

The tender submitted by the General Supply Company of Canada Limited is the only firm offering a generating unit of 20 K.V.A. capacity as specified. The capacity of equipment offered by the Canadian Fairbanks Morse Company Limited is 18.7 K.V.A. with 15% overload for intermittent duty and is satisfactory for the needs of the site. The capacity of the unit offered by the Northern Electric Company Limited is 25K.W., which accounts for their higher price, and we consider this unit too large for the needs of the Agency.

The lowest tender price for equipment as specified is in the amount of $4,068.00 f.o.b. Ottawa, submitted by the General Supply Company of Canada Limited, to which approximately $45.00 should be added to cover freight charges to Port Hill, P.E.I., making a total cost to the Department of $4,113.00 per unit with twelve to sixteen weeks delivery.

The tender submitted by the Canadian Fairbanks Morse Company Limited of Ottawa is in the amount of $4,886.00 f.o.b. Port Hill, P.E.I., per unit, with two to four weeks delivery.

There is a difference in price between the two offers of approximately $753.00 per unit delivered at the site and this, plus the fact that the equipment is of Canadian manufacture, makes the offer of the General Supply Company of Canada Limited more favourable, and it would appear satisfactory if Indian Affairs accepted this tender.

G.E.B. Sinclair, Esq.,
Acting Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,

Gentlemen:

Reference cheque No. 322-58760 in the amount of $140.67.

If you will refer to our Invoice, you will see this account was short paid $1.19.

If you will refer to your Purchase Order, carrying File No. 34548-15-F P.E.I., of 11th September, you will see that the order called for the stove to be shipped, f.o.b. Sackville. The order also has stamped on it asking us to charge the transportation charges to Port Hill, P.E.I., which would indicate that you expected to pay transportation. The amount of the prepay would have been shown on the Bill of Lading that went forward with the invoice.

We have checked with the Railway people, the shipment was delivered on a proper basis, freight was paid by us at your request, and now you have paid the Bill less the freight.

We presume that this was simply an oversight or misunderstanding. May we please have your remittance to secure this account.

Yours very truly,

ENAMEL & HEATING PRODUCTS LIMITED

[Signature]

F. F. Rand - Sales Manager

Gentlemen:

With reference to your letter of the 13th ultimo addressed to the Comptroller of Treasury, when we received your account including an item of $1.19 for transportation charges, we were unable to pay the latter item owing to our regulations which require that a receipt for transportation charges must accompany the account.

If you refer to Purchase Order 33882, you will note that it was stated on it that a receipted Voucher for transportation charges should accompany the Invoice.

We have now received the receipt from the Transportation Company, and payment of $1.19 will be arranged immediately.

Yours truly,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

With reference to your Voucher No. 352 issued in favour of Holman Limited, their first account dated 15th July, 1948, includes an item of $30.60 for 4 kegs of nails apparently purchased on 14th June, 1948.

You also attached to this Voucher an Invoice dated 14th June, 1948, requesting payment for 4 kegs of nails. It appears that this is a duplicate charge. Please let me know by return air mail if it is a duplication, in order to allow us to pass the account. I also note that you have forwarded us several other Vouchers in favour of Holman Limited, but you do not quote any Purchase Order. Presumably, you did not apply to us for a Purchase Order.

When will we receive all the accounts in connection with the erection of the buildings at Lennox Island. We requested this information in 2 or 3 previous letters, but have not yet received a definite reply from you. We will expect to hear from you by return mail.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division
