MEMORANDUM:

Re: Le Roi Island Indian Agency

During his recent visit to the Maritimes, our Mr. Macrae visited the above in accordance with a request made by Major D. A. MacKay in his memorandum of November 19, 1948, for the purpose of reporting on the mechanical services in connection with a group of agency buildings recently completed at the above, under the supervision of Mr. Morris of the Indian Affairs Branch. The following report is based on our officer's observations.

The group of buildings is comprised of the principal's residence, two classroom buildings, a school with teachers living quarters, dormitory, office and store, and master superintendent's residence.

Commenting on the work in general, it is pointed out that most of the materials used in these buildings were salvaged from the Mount Pleasant Air Field. Generally the construction appeared to have been fairly well executed in all the buildings. There are numerous discrepancies in the heating layouts, and these, with other detailed comments, are outlined below.

1. Principal's residence - Instead of building a new residence as originally planned, the existing old house was raised and provided with a basement, and the interior of the substructure was completely revised. A gravity warm air heating system was installed in accordance with manufacturers data. In principle, as far as possible, the layout is conventional; but in order to clear the basement stairs, it was necessary to introduce several sharp turns in the ducts, and the lack of heat may be expected in the room it serves. In another instance, a branch leader has been taken off as a means of saving labor during construction and to say the least, this is unorthodox, and can be expected to give trouble.

2. Classroom Indian Day School with Teachers' Quarters - The classrooms in this building were fitted in accordance with plans prepared by this Division, except for the teachers quarters which were built from plans prepared by the Department of National Health and Welfare, with some changes to ground floor partitions. The heating system is forced circulated hot water job installed with complete disregard for conventional methods. All the basement connections from the main return entry nozzles were installed on the mains, numerous air pockets are evident, and the connections at the boiler are all very poor. There is no provision to protect the boiler from large amounts of cold return water being pumped in, which could unlikely will result in serious damage to the boiler sections. Much old material and piping has been

used even to the extent of using old steam radiator traps in place of elbows. Nothing short of a complete plan revision would correct this layout, as all accepted standards have been ignored throughout. It will occasion no surprise if one or more of the radiators freeze up and burst before this heating season is over. In order to protect the boiler sections from splitting, the Indian Agent was advised to operate a reverse-acting aqua-stat and to have same wired into the main thermostat circuit, so that it will be impossible for large amounts of cold return water to collect in the main main.

3. Power House - This building was constructed to house the water pressure tank, pumping machinery and diesel generator unit. The concrete base for the generator set have been poured, and the anchor bolts set in place. The well casing is also in place but until the generator is installed, the new water pump will not be connected. At present an oversized water pump, procured from the Mount Pleasant Air Field, is being used to provide water and is being driven by a gasoline engine. The building appears to be satisfactory for the purpose it was intended.

4. Office and stores - This building was erected from salvaged lumber. No fault was evident. The warm air furnace has not arrived as yet, and in the meantime an oil fired circulating unit is used for heating this building.

5. Indian Superintendent's residence. This building was erected in accordance with the standard plan prepared by this Division. Several items could be criticized with reference to several points. Plaster in some rooms and the halls has cracked and edges of the interior wood finish has not been too well executed. The main stair rail and banister is not firm. This building is heated by a warm air furnace, generally installed in accordance with our plans, except that a space of only 42" from the wall to the fire door of the furnace has been allowed. There is no reason why this furnace should not have been located as shown on the drawing.

Since there was no record site plan showing how the buildings were arranged, our officer took field measurements and established locations of the buildings, tying back to a bench mark established by a previous surveyor. Dimensions, measurements and sketches of each individual building were made for record purposes. Sufficient information in connection with the mechanical services was obtained to enable recommendations to be made if required.

We have your letter of the 10th instant with reference to certain accounts about which we wrote to you on 1st February, 1949. Your answer regarding the Holman accounts is not exactly clear.

Purchase Order [28639] for $3,200.00 was issued to R.T. Holman on 10th April, 1948. Against this Purchase Order we have only received accounts amounting to $548.95. You understand, of course, that when a Purchase Order is issued the account forwarded should read exactly the same as the Purchase Order.

In the meantime, we have your Vouchers Nos. 28, 35, 40, 41, 42, 43, 334, 335 and 380, all of which are issued in favour of R.T. Holman, but you do not quote any Purchase Order on them.

Please advise us if any of these Vouchers should be charged to Purchase Order 28639. If so, this information should have been given when the Vouchers were forwarded.

If the items charged on the Vouchers mentioned are different from the items shown on Purchase Order 28639, it will be necessary for us to secure a new Purchase Order.

We will expect to hear from you by return airmail.

I note from your letter of 10th February, 1949, that all accounts and labour returns in connection with the erection of the buildings at Lennox Island will reach us by 25th February, 1949.

Bernard F. Neary,

Ottawa, March 11, 1949.

Memorandum:

Colonel B. F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Re: Voucher #130 - Amount $57.09.

In connection with Superintendent L.J. Daly's letter of the 9th instant regarding the above Voucher attached, please be advised as follows.

These groceries were purchased by the Mother Superior to provide refreshments for the people attending the official Opening of the School in September 1948. When the final arrangements were being made for this, I requested the Reverend Sisters, with the help of the Indian Women of the Homemaker's Club, to serve a lunch to the guests, as well as the officials who took part in this function. At the time I told the Superior that I did not know if the account could be paid from School Funds. However, I stated that every attempt would be made to have the account paid. The Indian women prepared the refreshments and served them under the supervision of the Reverend Sisters and, in my opinion, they did an excellent job. There were approximately 200 white people at this function, as well as all the Indians. I would say, roughly, 350 to 375 persons were provided with food.

I would recommend that this account be paid.

J. E. Morris,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies for the Province of Ontario.

Re: Financial status -
Lennox Island, P.E.I.

Our Superintendent, Mr. L.J. Daly, has recently advised that an additional $1,000.00 will be required to pay for labour to complete construction on Lennox Island. While investigating at Treasury regarding the financial status of this job, we ascertained that funds were already overexpended to the extent of $650.00.

While at Treasury we also ascertained that funds amounting to $5400.00 were being held by Treasury to pay two purchase orders issued April 10th, 1948 - Purchase Order No. 28682 issued by Indian Affairs to R.T. Holman Ltd. for materials to construct the Superintendent's residence amounted to $2200.00 and Purchase Order No. 28669 was issued by Education Division to R.T. Holman Ltd. for $3200.00 for a similar purpose.

Since these purchase orders were issued, many small orders for similar material were placed with R.T. Holman Ltd. for which invoices have been received and paid, and we have now been advised by Mr. L.J. Daly that the two original orders will not now be forwarded to Headquarters for payment, and should be cancelled. This action will release $5400.00 for other purposes in connection with Lennox Island construction and it will not be necessary, under the circumstances, to raise a further encumbrance requisition. Attached hereto are copies of our correspondence and wires on the subject, for your information.

Cont'd...
This office has already requested the Departmental Purchasing Agent to cancel Purchase Order No. 28688, and it would be advisable to have your office cancel Purchase Order No. 28689. Will you please advise this office when this action has been taken?

As soon as sufficient funds are realized by the cancellation of these purchase orders, this office will arrange to forward Mr. Daly our share, or 35%, of the additional and further accountable advance requested, namely, $350.00, and it would be appreciated if your office would take similar action to forward your share, or $650.00, as quickly as possible.

May we please be advised when your action has been completed?

Enclos.

W. F. Pratt,
General Executive Assistant.

Re: Further accountable advance and additional funds necessary to complete construction.

On January 3rd, 1949, we wrote you requesting further information regarding expenditures for buildings on your Agency. Later, on January 27th, we wrote you again stating that funds were entirely expended and we were at a loss to understand this situation, in view of the fact that E.R. No. 2219 was raised from funds transferred from another allotment, and it was assumed at that time that these funds would complete the work in accordance with your telegram dated November 7th, 1948. In the meantime, Treasury advises that in order to pay purchase orders and vouchers on hand at the present time, it will require an additional $650.00.

While checking on these figures with Treasury Department, we have ascertained that Treasury has set aside $5400.00 to pay two purchase orders as follows:

April 10, 1949 - Purchase Order 28688 to R. T. Holman Ltd., - $2200.00;
Purchase Order 28689 to R. T. Holman Ltd., - $3200.00.

(The latter purchase order was issued by the Education Division). Since these two purchase orders were issued, many small accounts have been received, attached to your vouchers, by R. T. Holman Ltd., some of which are similar to the items shown on the two purchase orders shown above, but certainly all the items covered in the original two purchase orders have not been invoiced by Holman Ltd. It would appear that the original two purchase orders will not be forwarded to Headquarters, attached to your voucher, for payment and in this case these two purchase orders should be cancelled, which will release $5400.00 for other purposes, and, therefore, an additional encumbrance requisition will not be necessary. Will you please check very carefully and advise us if we are correct in this regard.

Cont'd....
In connection with accountable advances, Treasury advises that they have forwarded you $13,060.00 to date and cash books show an expenditure of $13,054.00. However, credit vouchers received total $2,768.00. Will you, therefore, please see that credit vouchers for the remaining $10,287.00 are forwarded to headquarters as quickly as possible. This is a serious situation and should be corrected immediately.

Regulations require that credit voucher returns should be made each month and every two weeks, if possible, and we cannot understand why your returns should be allowed to drag on indefinitely.

Will you please let us have the information requested above as soon as possible in order that we may pay the vouchers on hand at Treasury and, at the same time, forward you an additional accountable advance which you have requested.

(sgd.) W. J. F. Pratt,
General Executive Assistant.

"SCHOOL

The school layout requires that pupils going to the lavatory must pass either through the other classroom or through the furnace-room. Neither method is satisfactory. The principal's residence is in need of a few minor repairs which could be arranged locally. This house is sparsely furnished. The four hundred and fifty dollars expended hardly made the house habitable."

Sir,

In reply to official letter of 13th inst. No. 130688 I have to inform that it was not my intention in any letter of 29th Oct. to ask the Department to incur any expenses in forcing Indians to carry out their agreement as to payment taxes.

The assessment was agreed upon at a meeting of the Indians and was for the purpose of raising money to pay for lighting fires, setting wood etc., at their School and was payable at the end of the School term to be held last. Some of the Indians refused to pay their assessments at this meeting as well as another assessment agreed upon to repair their roads. What I wished to know is, is there any way since these delinquents Indians to levy up? Can find nothing in the Indian Act bearing on the subject.

Your obedient servant,

OTTAWA, 15th August, 1896.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of 11th instant relative to the dispute between Miss D'Oloqui and Miss Babain, as to who is to remain in charge of the Big Cove school; and in reply I beg to say that a telegram was sent you to-day, which should read as follows:

"As Miss D'Oloqui intends teaching only six weeks, Miss Babain is to remain in charge of the Big Cove school."

In view of the difficulty likely to be experienced in procuring a suitable teacher when Miss D'Oloqui would wish to leave at the end of September, and of the fact that a frequent change of teacher is prejudicial to the progress of the pupils, the Department considers that it would not be justified in allowing Miss D'Oloqui to return for such a short period, especially as the Indians are well satisfied with Miss Babain. Miss D'Oloqui should have notified Miss Babain that she wished to resume her duties.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean

I have to report that Miss Nathalie Babin, teacher of the Big Cove Indian school is sick and will not be able to take charge of the school for three months at least. When I was in Big Cove holding an election there this week the Indians spoke to me about changing teachers. They stated that a certain teacher at Mission Point, in Restigouche, Province of Quebec was willing to take the school and requested me to engage her. She is a Micmac Indian woman. Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of last night would say that I am enclosing days programme which I have followed every day. Any irregularities would be due to the fact that children would not be present.

As to their complaint regarding drawing I have not taken up any time for that subject though it is considered quite an important one in schools for white children. I certainly never gave them a cat nor a dog to draw notwithstanding Big Cove to the contrary. But when finding children let seats were drawing I often gave them other work.
When I first began teaching I found the children reading in a monotonous tone of voice and with no understanding of subject read. I know they have improved in their reading.

After discussing the matter of their religious training with Rev. Father McLaughlin and Rev. Father Ryan I followed their instructions as regards teaching Catechism and prayers. It requires infinite time and patience but they have made some progress.

I have endeavored faithfully to do good work and regret that such complaint has been made for I feel it to be unjust.

How could such people report on my school work when they had never been in school any day while school was in session except the Chief who was in for a few minutes one day to see about wood for school. And Tom Sock was in to inform me that his children were to attend
school and that he was no longer a trustee.

They told me that "Cheech" was trusted and I do not see his name in report.

Thanking you for your kind attention, and knowing that you will take an impartial view of the matter, I remain,

yours respectfully,
Ray McInerney.

Ottawa, August 4, 1911.

Madam,

The Department is pleased to know that you have agreed to take charge of the Big Cove Indian School after the summer holidays. You should open the school on September 1st. It is hoped that you will find the work congenial and that you will meet with a large measure of success.

With regard to the class-room work it is not necessary to give you any instructions as you have had considerable experience as a teacher. The Department would, however, like you to take up some branch of domestic science, preferably the teaching of sewing to the girls. If you will consent to do this the necessary materials will be purchased for you when you open the school on the first of September. A certain length of time each day can then be allotted for this work.

You will be good enough to give special attention to the teaching of calisthenics and not less than ten minutes each day should be devoted to this. A copy of the manual for this purpose will be found in the school-room, but should there not be one there a copy will be sent you from the Department upon request.

I would also ask you to pay special attention to the teaching of hygiene using the Ontario Public School textbook.

The Department furnishes all supplies for the school-room and when you take up the work should you find yourself

Miss Kathlyn Sutton,
Bathurst,
Gloucester Co., N.B.
yourself in need of anything in the way of books and stationery I would ask you to be good enough to communicate with the Indian Agent, who will forward a requisition to the Department.

One of the difficulties that Indian teachers meet with is the apathy of the parents in respect to the education of their children. It would be well for you, therefore, to visit the parents in their homes frequently with a view of impressing upon them the necessity of sending their children regularly to school.

Short monthly reports upon your work would be very gladly received by the Department and any assistance in its power towards helping you in your work will be very gladly given.

Your obedient servant,
